text: George Michael has announced that a new documentary film about his life marks the beginning of his retirement from the public eye. The film, A Different Story, explores his career and personal struggles since the 1980s, and provides context to his 22 years of fame. Michael stated that he does not know what his future career will entail, but he will still be making music. The pop star expressed disappointment with the current state of the music industry and suggested that his genre of music is "dead." The film premiered at the Berlin Film Festival and has been shown on BBC One.

Lord Callaghan, the former Prime Minister of Britain, has passed away at the age of 92, just 11 days after his wife Audrey died aged 91. Lord Callaghan was the longest living former British PM in history and is survived by his son and two daughters. He held various prominent positions throughout his career, including that of chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary and prime minister. Lord Callaghan of Cardiff was also a committed public servant who entered parliament in 1945 when he was elected for a Cardiff constituency. His political career was not without controversy, however, and included conflicts with the hard left of the party and disagreements over policies such as the Common Market and the country's entry. Despite this, Lord Callaghan was remembered with fondness by politicians of all parties following his passing.

A Conservative election candidate named Danny Kruger is resigning after making a statement that he wanted a "period of creative destruction in the public services." Kruger had been scheduled to run against Tony Blair in Sedgefield. The Conservative Party claims Kruger's statement was taken out of context and that he supports their policies on public services. However, Kruger has decided not to contest the election in fear of damaging the Conservative Party's reputation. Kruger will remain in his job at the Tory campaign headquarters. The Labour Party has accused Kruger of exposing the Conservative agenda for cutting £35bn from public services.

Military leaders are set to meet and make a final decision about the future of Scotland's Army regiments. There are plans to restructure the regiments by cutting the six single-battalion regiments to five and merging them into a super regiment. These plans have faced opposition from campaigners and politicians alike. The decision made by the committee of senior defence figures must be ratified by the Defence Secretary and the Prime Minister. The proposed changes have sparked an outcry from Labour backbenchers, opposition politicians, and campaigners who threatened to stand against Labour in the next general election. There are concerns that the proposed restructuring will lead to recruitment problems and a loss of local connections and heritage. An alternative blueprint had been put forward, which proposed going ahead with the merger while preserving the other regiments. It seems unlikely that the Prime Minister will consider this plan, as he has hinted that a super regiment is likely. The government's aim is to preserve tradition while introducing a more effective structure.

The play "The History Boys" by Alan Bennett won two awards at the Critics' Circle Theatre Awards, with Richard Griffiths winning best actor for his role as teacher Hector. The play is set in a grammar school and has also won the best new comedy title at the Theatregoers' Choice Awards. Other winners included "The Producers" for best musical, Victoria Hamilton for best actress in "Suddenly Last Summer," and Rufus Norris for best director for "Festen." The Critics' Circle also awarded Rebecca Lenkiewicz as most promising playwright for "The Night Season," Eddie Redmayne as most promising newcomer for "The Goat or, Who is Sylvia?", Paul Rhys as best Shakespearean performer for "Measure for Measure," and Christopher Oram for best design for "Suddenly Last Summer." The Theatregoers' Choice Awards named Christian Slater best actor for "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," Diana Rigg best actress for "Suddenly Last Summer," Dame Judi Dench best supporting actress for the RSC's "All's Well That Ends Well," and Samuel Barnett best supporting actor for "The History Boys." Both award ceremonies were announced on Tuesday.

Tony Blair has supported the pre-Budget report by Chancellor Gordon Brown, despite opposition claims that he was too optimistic about the UK economy. Blair stated that the report highlights stability and opportunity, which are central to Labour's next election campaign. Brown denied that his economic forecasts were overly optimistic, but did not rule out future tax rises. Blair praised Brown for creating economic stability, which is the cornerstone of Labour's programme. The report predicts UK growth between 3% and 3.5%, which many experts believe to be too optimistic, leading to fears of tax rises or spending cuts. Conservative Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin accused Brown of using "fancy statistics" to hide public service failures, while Vincent Cable of the Liberal Democrats called for the government's books to be opened up to the National Audit Office to check if Brown had met his "golden rule."

Andre Agassi withdrew from the Kooyong Classic due to a hip injury, putting his participation in the Australian Open in doubt. He stopped the match against fellow American Andy Roddick at a score of 5-6 down in the first set due to his hip cramping. Agassi, who has previously won the Australian Open four times, will undergo an MRI scan to determine the degree of his injury. He mentioned that the hip injury he suffered last year while missing Wimbledon was not the current problem. He expressed concern over his condition and hopes to deal with it effectively. Time will inform whether he will still be able to participate in the Australian Open, and he will have a better sense of his prospects in a few days.

The president of Sri Lanka has started a rebuilding campaign worth 1.8 billion pounds after the devastation caused by a tsunami. The IMF estimates that the tsunami caused damage equal to 6.5% of the country's economy, and cut one percentage point from Sri Lanka's economic growth for this year. At least one million people lost their jobs in Sri Lanka and Indonesia due to the tsunami and as a result, the International Labour Organisation (ILO) is calling for job creation. The president is appealing for peace and national unity as a means to create a new beginning to rebuild the country with its numerous natural resources. The IMF anticipates that multiple industries including fishing, agriculture, and tourism will experience negative impacts due to the disaster, which could harm Sri Lanka's economic growth, inflation, and balance of payments.

Apple is facing criticism from the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) for attempting to force three American online journalists to disclose their sources for articles containing leaked information about unreleased Apple products, including the Mac Mini and product code-named Asteroid. The EFF argues that the journalists are protected by the American constitution and is representing the reporters in the legal battle against Apple. The case raises questions about the extent to which corporations can prevent information from being published and whether online journalists have the same privileges and protections as those writing for traditional media. The EFF has gained support from high-profile individuals and argues that if Apple succeeds in exposing the sources, it will deter potential confidential sources from providing information to the media, resulting in the public losing a vital outlet for independent news and commentary.

At the View From Great Edinburgh Cross Country, Eliud Kipchoge won the 9.2km race, beating Gebre Gebremariam and Dejene Berhanu from Ethiopia. Nick McCormick also won the 4km race, leading from the end of the first lap and beating Mike Skinner and Andrew Baddeley. In the women's race, Tirunesh Dibaba from Ethiopia beat Benita Johnson to retain her title. Britons Kathy Butler and Hayley Yelling were not competitive in the race. McCormick was confident in his training and hopes to make the British team for the World Championships in Helsinki.

The organisers of the London Marathon are optimistic that Susan Chepkemei, who has been banned from competition by Athletics Kenya for not attending a training camp, will still compete in the race on April 17th. David Bedford, the race director, said that they are monitoring the situation and hoping for a satisfactory resolution before the event. Chepkemei participated and finished third in the world best 10K race in Puerto Rico despite the suspension. She has been the runner-up to Paula Radcliffe in the 2002 and 2003 London Marathons, as well as the New York City Marathon in November 2004.

The movie Ocean's Twelve, a sequel to Ocean's Eleven with George Clooney, Brad Pitt, and Julia Roberts, has become the number one movie in the US box office, earning $40.8m in ticket sales during its opening weekend. The plot follows the master criminals as they plan three major heists across Europe. The film's success makes it the fourth-biggest December release in the US after the Lord of the Rings trilogy. It beat Ocean's Eleven's opening weekend gross of $38.1m and went on to earn $184m in total. Despite mixed reviews, it is considered a fun holiday movie and is directed by Steven Soderbergh, who directed the first movie. Catherine Zeta-Jones joins the cast.

The Japanese economy grew by only 0.1% in the three months prior to September. This was below expectations and caused concern as Japan's economy had been stagnant for a long period of time. The weak growth can be attributed to faltering exports, subdued domestic demand, and insufficient corporate investment. Japan's economy has become increasingly dependent on exports for recovery, but high oil prices and the falling dollar have affected this. This is a significant downturn from earlier in the year, with the first quarter showing growth of 6.3% and the second quarter showing 1.1%. While personal consumption looks good, it is mainly due to temporary factors such as the Olympics. The government may find it challenging to implement policies such as raising taxes to deal with the public debt when the economy picks up.

China's economy grew at a higher than expected rate of 9.5% in 2004, which could lead to limits on investment and lending as Beijing works to cool down the economy. While industrial growth has slowed, services have been a driving force behind growth. However, consumer prices rose at a faster rate, causing concern over inflation. China's exports have also surged due to the relatively cheap yuan. Despite calls to change the currency's exchange rate, officials say they are not ready to shift to a more market-driven rate. Overall, the economy remains strong, with no signs of a slowdown in 2005.

New figures from the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) show that UK consumers are the world's biggest music buyers. However, despite growing sales in DVD music videos, the global sales of recorded music remained flat in 2004 due to online and physical piracy in major markets. The UK music industry saw a 3% growth in volume sales, driven mostly by its strong album market. Despite this, world music sales declined by 1.3% to $33.6 billion (£17.7 billion). The US and UK had the largest number of album releases in 2004. The BPI chairman attributed the overall sales growth to new UK-signed artists, such as Keane, Katie Melua, and Scissor Sisters. Although digital sales in the US were booming, many markets in Continental Europe and Asia were severely affected by internet piracy. The IFPI CEO stated that the priority for the coming year is to increase legitimate digital sales and sustain anti-piracy efforts.

Sandra, the former model and wife of Conservative party leader Michael Howard, will have a significant role in the party's election campaign. She will be visiting target seats alone and also accompanying her husband on his campaign trail via helicopter. Michael Howard will host a daily news conference at the Conservative party's London headquarters to increase accessibility to the public. This move is in contrast to Tony Blair's campaign strategy, as there are no plans for him to hold daily news conferences. The Liberal Democrats also plan to hold daily news conferences but with their party leader, Charles Kennedy. Sandra Howard has already been campaigning alongside her husband and has also given a speech about drug charities. She will continue to be part of her husband's campaign.

The term "blog" has been named the top word of 2004 by Merriam-Webster, a US dictionary publisher, as it was the most looked-up word on their site during the year. Blogs, or web logs, have become increasingly popular during 2004 and some have even started to influence mainstream media. The Merriam-Webster list also included terms related to major news events such as the US presidential election or natural disasters that hit the US. Blogs come in various forms and are used for different purposes such as news sites, political commentary, and lists of interesting websites. Online journals have become popular due to the easy-to-use software and the number of blogs in existence has doubled every five and a half months for the last 18 months, with over 4.8 million blogs in existence, though less than a quarter of them are regularly maintained. Blogs have become a means for many ordinary workers to share their daily lives, and in repressive regimes and developing nations, they have been used by millions of people to express their struggles.

The government of Japan has stated that it expects the country's economic growth to slow down to 1.6% in the upcoming fiscal year beginning in April 2005, down from the current rate of 2.1%. However, they claim that they are making progress towards ending deflation, and predict that the economy will grow by 2% in 2006/07. The economics minister, Heizo Takenaka, stated that the consumer price index (CPI) would rise by 0.1% in the next fiscal year, which would be the first increase since 2000/01. Takenaka believes that the government is on the right path towards improving real economic conditions and overcoming deflation. For over five years, Japan has been suffering from deflation, and to combat this issue, the Bank of Japan has been regularly injecting excess cash into the money market to maintain short-term interest rates at 0% and boost economic activity.

The animated movie Shark Tale, which received an Oscar nomination, has become the top-selling home video in the US following its release on DVD, making $80 million in its first week. The amount of money earned from DVD and video sales far exceeded its first week box office takings, and it has become the sixth highest-earning DVD for first week sales. The movie sold more than six million DVDs and videos across the United States and Canada, and is the highest first-week earner for February, outpacing My Big Fat Greek Wedding. Typically, films that are expected to generate strong home video earnings are released during the busiest retail season, which falls before Christmas. Shrek 2 was the best-selling home video of last year, with North American sales alone estimated at $458 million.

An American TV network is editing the BBC movie Dirty War to remove a scene that shows a nude woman being washed after a fictional chemical attack to avoid indecency complaints from US TV watchdogs. Many US broadcasters are now cautious about showing such scenes after the US Federal Communications Commission fined CBS $550,000 last fall for a wardrobe malfunction during a dance routine. PBS, which is a non-profit media company, is opting to show the edited version as it is financially safer and could discourage individual stations from broadcasting the film. PBS is considered a trusted community resource in the US, providing programming for almost 100 million viewers each week.

The Bafta Interactive Awards, which started in 1997, recognize excellent websites, digital TV shows, and CD roms. This year's awards have nearly 400 entries, which is a lot more than last year. The BBC has 16 nominations and The Guardian has three nominations. The winners from 12 different categories are announced on 2 March 2005. Categories include interactive TV, film, digital TV, mobile phones, and music. The BBC leads with the most nominations, including one for the Radio Times website and Sport Interactive's Euro 2004 coverage. Other nominees include The Guardian news website, the National Theatre, MTV, the Science Museum, and the London Stock Exchange. The awards split into separate games and interactive ceremonies in 2002 to fully cover the range of innovation outside the gaming industry.

The South Bank Show Awards, which usually celebrate highbrow and innovative culture, have honored popular soap opera Coronation Street as the first soap to win the best TV drama prize. The show beat out other nominated programs such as Filthy Love and Shameless. Other winners included Little Britain for best comedy, Franz Ferdinand for music, Dead Man's Shoes for best film, and David Mitchell for best literary work. The awards reflect the industry's achievements of the past year and have previously been won by shows such as The Lost Prince and the movie Bloody Sunday. Other winners in different categories were Alan Bennett for theater, and Paul Abbott and Amma Asante for lifetime achievement and breakthrough, respectively.

A large number of schools in the UK have signed up to participate in a mock general election supported by the government. The Y Vote Mock Elections 2005, run by the Hansard Society, aims to increase interest in politics among students. By taking part, students will learn the skills required to become political candidates, canvassers, and speechwriters. The program has been endorsed by Schools Minister Stephen Twigg, who believes that engaging young people in politics is vital for the future of democracy. The initiative is being run by the Hansard Society, the Electoral Commission, and the Department for Education and Skills. The mock elections will take place around the time of the real general election, and schools will receive information packs, including manifesto guides, and ballot papers.

Campaigners are rallying for the reopening of the Borders rail link, which was shut down in 1969. They plan to have a walk at Tweedbank to commemorate the 36th anniversary of the line closure. The Campaign for Borders Rail believes that the reopening of the Waverley Line will revive the area's economy. Members of the Scottish Parliament are considering reintroducing passenger rail services to the Borders. If the Waverley Line were to reopen, it could cost up to £100m and provide a significant economic boost for the Borders. In 2000, the Borders Council concluded that the area's economy had suffered since the closure. The Campaign for Borders Rail is asking the Scottish Executive to commit to funding the first phase of the project by restoring the line between Edinburgh and Tweedbank. They believe that reopening the line will be a prosperous move that preserves the character of the Scottish Borders. A review in 2000 concluded that a half-hourly service from Tweedbank to Edinburgh could cover its running expenses, as could the service from Gorebridge to Edinburgh. A freight railway linking the West Coast Main Line at Longtown was also found to be restorable.

Peter Molyneux, who is the head of Surrey's Lionhead Studios, has been awarded the OBE in the New Year Honours list for his contributions to the computer games industry. He is regarded as the mastermind behind many famous games, such as Populous, Theme Park, Dungeon Keeper, and Black and White. His induction into the OBE came as a surprise to him, as he never thought computer gaming would become such a huge industry. Peter Molyneux is recognized as an essential figure in the gaming world for nearly 20 years. In 1987, he started his career at Bullfrog Studios, and it took off from there. He left Bullfrog to set up the Lionhead Studios and was responsible for creating ambitious and highly praised games like Black & White. He still has one problem to solve before picking up his OBE: what to wear.

Scotland's back row troubles have increased as Scott Gray has been ruled out of the opening matches of the RBS Six Nations due to a knee injury. He joins Donnie Macfadyen and Allister Hogg on the injured list, while Simon Taylor, Scott MacLeod and Jon Petrie are also doubtful for the first game. Andrew Wilson of Glasgow is out for a month with ligament damage to both knees, while Jason White and Tom Smith have missed practice due to flu. The coach is considering options such as Alasdair Strokosch and Simon Cross from Edinburgh, and Jon Dunbar from Leeds Tykes.

Federer joins all-time greats The last year has seen one player dominate men's tennis, and one country dominate the women's game. Roger Federer became the first man since Mats Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slams in one season. And after Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open, two more followed at Wimbledon and the US Open. Meanwhile, Briton Tim Henman enjoyed his best year, while Greg Rusedski fought back superbly from adversity. Federer began the year as world number one and holder of the Wimbledon and Masters Cup titles, and set about conquering new ground. The Swiss sounded warning of the dominance to come at the Australian Open. He ripped through the draw before beating Marat Safin in the final. Andy Roddick was the only player to put up any real resistance at Wimbledon, and Federer's performance against Lleyton Hewitt in the US Open final was breathtaking. Federer again got the better of Hewitt in the season-ending Masters Cup. His victory in Houston proved to be his 13th successive win in a final, an Open era record. The only major let-down was a third-round loss to Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open, and Roland Garros will be his main target in 2005. There was also a surprise loss to the unheralded Tomas Berdych at the Olympic Games, which saw Chile dominate as Nicoals Massu took the singles and then paired up with Fernando Gonzaelz to win doubles gold. Another major trophy that looks beyond Federer is the Davis Cup, which was won by Spain in a 3-2 home success over the USA in Seville. Roddick struggled on the clay, losing to Rafael Nadal on the opening day before going down to Carlos Moya in the all-important fourth rubber. Henman broke new ground by reaching the semis on clay at the French Open - a stunning effort - and also at the US Open. A quarter-final defeat to Mario Ancic at Wimbledon was disappointing for the limp manner of the Briton's defeat, but he remains optimistic of going further next year. British number two Rusedski endured a rollercoaster year, returning to the circuit after being cleared of a doping offence in March. With his ranking down at 168, many feared the 31-year-old's career was over, but he battled back in the second half of the season to re-enter the top 50. The Russian women finally delivered on their long-recognised promise in 2004, with Myskina, Maria Sharapova and Svetlana Kuznetsova winning Grand Slams, before taking the season-ending Fed Cup. But while the young Russians were on the way up, it was a different story for the Belgians and the Williams sisters. Only veteran Lindsay Davenport held the new wave at bay, a stunning run of form after Wimbledon taking her to number one ahead of Amelie Mauresmo, whose Grand Slam drought goes on. The year started in regulation fashion as Justine Henin-Hardenne beat compatriot Kim Clijsters at the Australian Open. A virus ruined the rest of Henin-Hardenne's year, although she was fit enough to win Olympic gold, but Clijsters had an even more miserable 2004. She suffered a serious wrist injury and then announced the end of her relationship with Lleyton Hewitt, and will be happy to see the year end. In their absence, Myskina thrashed Elena Dementieva in a historic, but woeful, all-Russian final at the French Open. Wimbledon was a more refreshing affair as Sharapova captivated SW19, showing nerves of steel as she battled past Davenport and Serena Williams to take the title. Davenport was a strong favourite for the US Open but, hampered by injury, lost to the powerful and unflappable Kuznetsova in the semis. Kuznetsova went on to give Dementieva another Grand Slam final thrashing, with the latter's wayward serve becoming one of the talking points of the year. With the Russians still improving, the likes of Henin-Hardenne, Clijsters, Davenport, Mauresmo, Venus and Serena will need to be fully fit and motivated in 2005. And it may take their compatriot Safin to challenge Federer on the men's side.

The CEO of Hewlett Packard, Carly Fiorina, spoke at the Consumer Electronics Show about the company's goal to fully converge the digital and physical worlds so that people can be at the center of technology. She emphasized the democratization of technology and the vast amount of stories and experiences that have been made possible by the digital revolution. HP is working on making devices more compatible with each other to allow for easier transfer of content such as images, video, and music. Personalization and lifestyle are important themes at the CES, with wearable MP3 players and colorful gadgets everywhere. Fiorina announced new products such as the Digital Media Hub and a visual radio service, and also revealed that HP would be partnering with MTV for the upcoming Asia Aid event aimed at raising money for the Asian tsunami disaster.

The US dollar has reached a new low against the euro due to concerns about the US economy, including its trade and budget deficits. Other countries have called for coordinated currency controls to prevent economic catastrophe. November data has also shown a decline in consumer spending and home sales, causing further concerns about the US economy. While the official US policy is to support a strong dollar, some believe that the country benefits from a weaker currency due to increased exports. The dollar's downward trend is expected to continue in 2005.

Actress Annette Bening, known for her outstanding performances, has finally received an Oscar nomination for her role in the acclaimed film "Being Julia". Even though she has been a popular Hollywood figure for a while and has been nominated for Academy Awards before, she is yet to win. Bening started her career in theatre and television before making her debut in the film industry. Her breakthrough role was in "The Grifters", followed by playing Virginia Hill in "Bugsy". Her exceptional acting in "American Beauty" was also highly appreciated, but she could not win the award. However, her latest performance in "Being Julia" has won her accolades, including the Golden Globe Award, and she is now considered a strong contender for the Oscar.

David Blunkett has unveiled new plans to improve policing in England and Wales. The plans include the creation of a dedicated policing team for each neighborhood, a 10-point customer charter, and a new non-emergency phone number for police calls. Local residents could also be given the mobile phone number of their local police officer, and could "trigger" action on specific problems if they felt nothing was being done. Local councillors would need to meet certain conditions before invoking the power, and frivolous complaints would be refused if they caused annoyance or posed too heavy a burden on police resources. Mr. Blunkett also plans to recruit an additional 25,000 Community Support Officers and promised £50m to recruit 2,000 new CSOs. The best-performing police services would receive more funding and extra freedoms, but the home secretary would not hesitate to intervene where the public was being failed. The plans have been criticized by the opposition parties for tying up the police with paperwork and being little more than a "taxpayer-funded PR exercise," but some politicians have praised the government's efforts to increase links between local people and the police.

The Bafta film awards ceremony is taking place with movie stars from around the world attending. There are several nominees in multiple categories including British stars Imelda Staunton and Clive Owen along with Hollywood stars Leonardo DiCaprio, Pierce Brosnan, Christian Slater, and Richard Gere. The Aviator movie leads with the most nominations. The best actress nominee Staunton arrived wearing a green silk dress and hopes to win for her role in a small-budget film. Other nominees in the same category include Charlize Theron, Ziyi Zhang, and Kate Winslet. In the best actor category, DiCaprio competes with others like Jamie Foxx and Johnny Depp. The ceremony will be broadcast on BBC One.

The problem of online security fears is affecting the potential of e-commerce as customers are increasingly concerned about cyber attacks such as phishing and identity theft. A recent survey found that almost 70% of respondents did not believe that online companies were doing enough to protect their personal information. This is worrying for businesses and customers who want to use the internet for financial transactions. Although more people are becoming aware of the threat, they have little faith that companies are doing enough to counter it. Experts recommend that both parties need to take responsibility to prevent fraud by ensuring extra security measures are in place. One of the biggest challenges to improving security online is how to authenticate an individual's identity. Passwords are easily compromised, and several security companies have developed alternative methods such as biometric measurement or token-based systems to provide a single online identity. For example, Activcard has developed a one-time passcode generation technology that uses the chip embedded in bank cards and a special card reader to generate unique codes that are active for a specified amount of time. This method is being trialed with UK banks and could be a more secure way to conduct online transactions.

Labour and the Tories are in a dispute over tax and spending plans, with the argument over Gordon Brown's budget turning into a pre-election battle. Tony Blair accused the Tory government of planning to cut £35bn from public services that will affect schools, hospitals, and police, while the Tories claim that Labour's statements are misrepresentation and smear tactics. The Lib Dems criticized Brown for avoiding the issue of council tax rises. Brown and Blair came together at a Labour poster launch and claimed that the Tories would cut the same amount from public services, which is equal to sacking every doctor and teacher in the UK. The Tories deny the allegations and claim that not a single doctor, teacher, or nurse will be cut. Meanwhile, Vince Cable of the Lib Dems argued that Brown failed to deal with the revaluation of council tax bands, resulting in significant increases for some. The House of Commons authorities have told MPs that their offices will be deep cleaned during the three-week poll campaign.

A group of artists in Poland has taken the sounds made by the Nintendo GameBoy console and turned them into a unique style of music that they call "blip-pop". The Gameboyzz Orchestra Project uses six Nintendo GameBoys connected through a mixing board to create music, with each member improvising and providing a different sound. The group plays experimental music and aims to be unique by only playing original tracks. They have received both positive and mixed reactions from audiences, and hope to release a CD next year with the help of their sponsor, the Polish distributor of Nintendo products. However, due to the high cost of the GameBoy Advance in Poland, the group does not expect much competition from other musicians anytime soon.

Work and Pensions Secretary Alan Johnson has cautioned that the Child Support Agency (CSA) could be closed down if it does not improve its services. This would be a "nuclear option," he added. The Commons work and pensions committee called for the agency to be shut down if it fails to improve, and recommended contingency plans, including an option to abandon the new computer system. Johnson did not rule out the possibility of moving to a completely new system, but stressed that this would only happen if the government were convinced that the current system was irremediable. The CSA has been criticized for delays and inaccurate calculations, and a £720 million backlog of outstanding payments from absent parents. The government has suspended its plan to reduce the agency's staff by 25%, following the committee's criticism.

28 individuals, including a British citizen, have been arrested in a global operation targeting a website accused of identity fraud. The website, Shadowcrew.com, is alleged to be a global centre for criminals engaged in credit card fraud. Operation Firewall, led by the US Secret Service, involved seven countries and resulted in indictments for 19 individuals in Newark, New Jersey. The British teenager was arrested in connection with this operation and released on bail. The authorities estimated that the fraud caused losses of over $4m. The suspects were involved in an internet-based network that stole people's identities and used computers and websites for fraudulent activities. The investigation lasted 15 months and involved 30 law enforcement agencies worldwide. The Shadowcrew website listed several discussion groups, with members using it for organised crime purposes, including trafficking counterfeit credit cards and false identification materials. The website has since been taken over by the Secret Service. Mick Deats, the head of the NHTCU, warned that while the internet offers great benefits, it also has opportunities for criminals seeking to abuse those benefits for criminal gain.

According to research by Ericsson, phone companies should focus on how handsets fit in with people's lifestyles rather than just promoting better technology. The study found that consumers are more interested in how phones fit with their habits and routines rather than the technical specifications. The research also showed that people tend to use phones in similar ways to other devices for activities like diary-writing but are attracted to the convenience of using their mobiles. Ericsson noted that consumers break down into different groups or "tribes" who use phones in different ways, and early adopters tend to drive the adoption of new features, which gradually shape new habits and lifestyles.

Newcastle's manager, Graeme Souness, is finalizing a deal to sign Chelsea's defender, Celestine Babayaro, during the upcoming transfer window. Souness aims to strengthen his team's defense, and negotiations with Babayaro are reportedly in the advanced stages. Babayaro has been playing in the Premiership since 1997 and was bought by Chelsea for £2.25m from Anderlecht. This season, however, he has not been used much by the club. While Souness did not confirm any particular players, he did mention that the chairman has been working hard to make deals and that they aim to strengthen their team over the next few weeks.

According to local newspaper reports, Algeria has faced violent protests over the weekend due to the government's decision to increase gas prices. There were demonstrations in various regions, causing disruptions such as roadblocks, attacks on public buildings, and destruction of vehicles. This increase in the price of butane gas, an essential fuel for cooking, has led to further resentment in some of the country's poorest regions, where economic conditions are already failing. Earlier, there were demonstrations against the price change, but police had restored order. However, reports suggest that trouble escalated over the weekend, especially in towns close to Bouira, and the Tiaret and Sidi Ammar regions. Plus, the Maghnia region witnessed riots close to the Moroccan border. Algerians residing in remote mountain areas primarily use butane gas and fuel oil to cook and heat their homes.

WMC Resources, an Australian mining company, has rejected a $7.4bn takeover bid from rival Xstrata, claiming that its true value is 30% higher than the offer. A report by investment firm Grant Samuel, included in the company's defence documents, valued WMC shares at between A$7.17 to A$8.24 each, compared to Xstrata's offer of A$6.35. This report has provided more details on WMC to trigger a potential rival bid, which may emerge in the next one to two weeks, according to analysts. There is now increasing pressure on Xstrata to increase its offer as a result of this valuation. Xstrata has stated that it will review the document but has raised scepticism about the optimistic assumptions made.

Labour's election chief, Alan Milburn, has defended his party's campaign posters against claims of anti-Semitism by the Tories. Milburn affirmed that the posters were anti-Tory and not anti-Semitic. He acknowledged the concerns of the public and said that he respected their views. The controversy erupted after Labour released posters that seemed to portray Conservative leader Michael Howard, who is Jewish, as Fagin and a flying pig. The Tories accused Labour of a calculated campaign of sly anti-Semitism.  Labour withdrew the controversial posters, and four new designs were launched. The new posters avoided the Fagin and flying pig portrayals but continued to target Howard personally. The new posters were chosen by Labour supporters after the earlier posters were taken off the website.

The CEO of US TV network Fox, Gail Berman, has acknowledged that the company has relied too much on reality TV shows, including the poorly-rated program Who's Your Daddy. This caused the network's prime-time audience to fall by 600,000 to 5.9 million. Berman recognized that while Fox's audience expects loud content, not all of their reality shows have been successful. Despite the fact that the network had promised to launch new shows every season, the strategy was not well-received. Berman is predicting lower ratings even for Fox's established reality shows, such as American Idol. The network has changed its plan for new show launches, now unveiling them in May instead of June. One of the new shows will be American Dad, an animated series created by Seth MacFarlane, who also created Family Guy.

Top executives at the Chinese milk company Yili have been detained by the police on suspicion of embezzlement. Yili, one of China's leading milk producers, has confirmed that its chairman, chief financial officer, and securities representative are in custody. This follows media speculation about financial irregularities at the company, with executives being accused of misusing company funds for a management buyout in 2003. Yili's shares have been suspended, and there are concerns that this latest scandal is just the beginning of further revelations of corporate wrongdoing in China.

IBM puts cash behind Linux push IBM is spending $100m (£52m) over the next three years beefing up its commitment to Linux software. The cash injection will be used to help its customers use Linux on every type of device from handheld computers and phones right up to powerful servers. IBM said the money will fund a variety of technical, research and marketing initiatives to boost Linux use. IBM said it had taken the step in response to greater customer demand for the open source software. In 2004 IBM said it had seen double digit growth in the number of customers using Linux to help staff work together more closely. The money will be used to help this push towards greater collaboration and will add Linux-based elements to IBM's Workplace software. Workplace is a suite of programs and tools that allow workers to get at core business applications no matter what device they use to connect to corporate networks. One of the main focuses of the initiative will be to make it easier to use Linux-based desktop computers and mobile devices with Workplace. Even before IBM announced this latest spending boost it was one of the biggest advocates of the open source way of working. In 2001 it put $300m into a three-year Linux program and has produced Linux versions of many of its programs. Linux and the open source software movement are based on the premise that developers should be free to tinker with the core components of software programs. They reason that more open scrutiny of software produces better programs and fuels innovation.

Star Trek fans are currently fighting to save the show Star Trek: Enterprise, which is set to end in May after four series. They have paid for a full-page ad in the Los Angeles Times and are urging TV executives not to scrap the show. They are also hoping the Sci-Fi Channel will save the show and have organized a rally in Los Angeles on 25 February. Fans believe that the Star Trek franchise is a cultural icon and are trying to raise $32m to pay for a fifth series. The fourth series of Star Trek: Enterprise has received half the amount of viewers it received during its first series. The show began in 2001 and stars Quantum Leap actor Scott Bakula as Captain Archer.

The Treasury has announced that Chancellor Gordon Brown will present his Budget to the House of Commons on March 16th, likely to be the last before the General Election. The Budget will take place at around 12:30 pm after Prime Minister's Question Time on that Wednesday. During the annual event, the Chancellor will outline the government's taxation and broader economic predictions. The Tories predicted that the Budget could contain measures to attract votes ahead of the expected May election. The Finance Bill will have to be rushed through Parliament with all-party support if a May election is called. Accountancy firm Ernst & Young urged Brown to focus on the long-term economy rather than politics.

The Bravery, a New York-based electro-rock group, have topped the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll for promising new musical acts. They were heavily praised by 110 impartial critics and broadcasters for their debut single "Unconditional". Other new artists in the list include London indie group Bloc Party and UK rapper Kano. The Bravery have been compared to The Cure and New Order and have supported bands including The Libertines, Echo and the Bunnymen, and Interpol. Chris Hawkins, host of BBC 6 Music's chart show, praised the band for their "great guitars and a mastery of the electro-clash sound." The artists in the top ten were chosen by critics who were each asked to tip three acts they believed could achieve top musical success.

If LG Group, the former parent company of LG Card, does not support a $1.1bn rescue package for the credit card firm, the creditors have threatened to put the company into liquidation. LG Card has already been bailed out once before in 2004, but now needs more funding to avoid delisting from the Korea Stock Exchange. However, LG Group has said that it will not accept an unfair burden and wants fair guidelines on how to split the financial burden with the creditors who now own 99.3% of LG Card. The creditors have asked the government to mediate to avoid any risk to the stability of financial markets, and analysts believe a compromise is likely.

Jez San, the founder of Argonaut games group, has successfully bought back two of the three company subsidiaries that were placed under administration due to a severe cash crisis. Just Add Monsters studios and Morpheme, based in Cambridge and London respectively, have been saved as going concerns and over 40 jobs have been protected. The Argonaut software division in Edgware is still up for sale, and former employees who were fired during the crisis have expressed anger at the way the situation was handled. San, a veteran games developer and key figure in the UK games industry, had warned of annual losses of £6m in August.

A new proposal from Malcolm Glazer, a US tycoon, has resulted in a 4.75% rise in Manchester United's share value. The club's board is set to meet to discuss the proposal, which values the club at £800m ($1.5bn). Although earlier proposals from Glazer were rejected, this latest one is more detailed and will receive greater consideration. However, fans' group Shareholders United have called for the club to reject the proposal. Glazer's sons are leading the deal, and a proposal was received last week, with a suggested share price of 300p. For success, Glazer needs the support of the club's largest shareholders, JP McManus and John Magnier. NM Rothschild is advising Glazer on the proposal.

BBC digital radio station, 6 Music, will be taken over by Welsh band Manic Street Preachers for a week in December. The group has already selected their choice of records to play, including Who's Next by The Who and U2's Joshua Tree. They will also perform their own live session, and bass player Nicky Wire will appear on Phil Jupitus' show, while James Dean Bradfield will join Andrew Collins' show. The band has handpicked documentaries and live concert session tracks, including The Leonard Cohen Story and The Specials' Rat Race. They will also be answering questions from 6 Music listeners. This follows Radiohead's takeover of the station for a week last year.

A US magazine, Mobile PC, has compiled a list of the top 100 gadgets of all time, with the Apple Powerbook 100 taking the number one spot. The 1991 laptop was selected because it was one of the first lightweight portable computers and helped to define the layout of future notebook PCs. The list includes a variety of gadgets, including the Sony Walkman and Zenith remote control. Staff at the magazine compiled the list, specifying that gadgets needed to be self-contained and potentially mobile. The oldest gadget on the list is the abacus, and the newest is the Tivo personal video recorder. The list has been subject to criticism, with some arguing that certain items, like laptops, should not count as gadgets, while others feel that items like the marine chronometer and the sextant should be rated more highly.

The leader of the Conservative party, Michael Howard, has admitted that during his school years he used to skip class in order to play snooker with his friends at Jack's Snooker Hall in Llanelli, Wales. Despite this, he claims that it did not cause any long-term damage and that he does not regret his actions, but stipulates that truancy is a serious issue and that strong measures should be taken to prevent it. He also advocates for a return to O-levels and greater discipline in the classroom. Other famous snooker players such as Jimmy White have also admitted to skipping classes to play snooker instead.

Pixies take on Reading and Leeds Pixies, Foo Fighters and Iron Maiden will headline this summer's Leeds and Reading festivals. The trio of rock heavyweights will top the bill for the three-day events at Bramham Park, near Wetherby, and at Richfield Avenue, Reading. They are the Pixies' and Iron Maiden's only UK festival gigs, while Foo Fighters are also at T In The Park. The Killers, Razorlight and Queens of the Stone Age are also playing the twin festivals, to be held on 26-28 August. Other acts in this year's line-up include The Charlatans, Marilyn Manson and Kings of Leon. Pete Doherty's band Babyshamblers will appear on the NME/Radio One stage along with Kasabian, Black Rebel Motorcycle Club and Bloc Party. Organiser Mean Fiddler said more acts were still to be confirmed for the summer event. "We are all very excited to be going back to Reading and intend to have a fantastic time," said Iron Maiden's Bruce Dickinson. "We're sure fans will too." It will the first time the veteran British metal band have played Reading in 23 years. At Leeds, Iron Maiden will headline the first day of the festival on the Friday, Pixies will follow on Saturday and the Foo Fighters will close the event on Sunday. The Pixies will headline the first day of Reading, while Foo Fighters will play on Sunday and Iron Maiden will close the event. Weekend tickets are now on sale priced at £125 each.

According to the Hollywood Reporter, Friends actress Lisa Kudrow will be starring in a new HBO comedy series called "Comeback," which has been commissioned for thirteen episodes. HBO, the channel that produced hits such as Sex And The City, is looking for their next big comedy hit after the end of the Sex And The City series. Kudrow, who played Phoebe in Friends, co-wrote the pilot episode of Comeback and is also an executive producer. The series is about a one-time sitcom star, and it is the first 30-minute comedy that HBO has picked up since the end of Sex And The City. The article also provides updates on the other Friends stars and their upcoming projects.

European leaders are urging Asian states to allow their currencies to rise against the US dollar in order to alleviate the pressure on the euro. The euro has reached record high levels against the dollar in recent months, partly due to the US government's approval for a weaker dollar to address their deficits. Europe is now asking Asia to share the burden and increase currency flexibility, with China being pointed out as the main culprit due to their exporting success with a currency pegged to the dollar. This plea from Europe has caused a decrease in the euro's value, and further pressure is expected ahead of a meeting of G7 industrialised nations.

The children's Bafta awards were held and more than 6,000 children voted for their favorite film, and Shrek 2 won. The Bafta experts voted Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban as the best feature film. The BBC One Saturday morning show Dick and Dom In Da Bungalow won two awards, while former Playschool presenter Floella Benjamin received a Special Award for her contributions to children's film and television. Other winners included Joko!Jakamoko!Toto! for best pre-school animation and Debbie Isitt for best adapted writer for her work on The Illustrated Mum. Various categories, such as Schools Factual and Pre-School Live Action, were also awarded. An international category was won by 8 Simple Rules for Dating my Teenage Daughter.

The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is underway in Las Vegas, with around 120,000 people expected to attend. The annual event showcases new technologies and gadgets that will be released to the public over the next year. Exhibitors will present about 50,000 new products, with a specific focus on technologies that give people greater control over their multimedia content. Keynote speeches will be delivered by prominent figures in tech, including Microsoft's Bill Gates, who is expected to announce details about the next generation Xbox. CES organisers predict that consumer electronics will continue to experience significant growth, with personalisation and democratisation of content being key trends to watch.

Halifax has reported a 1.1% monthly increase in UK house prices for December, the first rise since September. The country's largest mortgage lender said prices rose 15.1% over the whole of 2004. However, this rate slowed to only 2.8% for the second half of the year. The average cost of a house in the UK is now £162,086. This data seems to contradict much recent evidence that the housing market has slowed due to interest rate increases. Capital Economics have disputed these figures, as they predict a fall in UK house prices, claiming that Halifax's report is only a temporary surprise. Responding to the figures, Martin Ellis, Halifax's Chief Economist stated that there was a genuine slowdown in the housing market. Halifax has confirmed their prediction from the previous month, that prices will fall by 2% in 2005, adding that sound housing market fundamentals will keep the market healthy, ensuring only a slight fall in house prices.

Microsoft has launched a pilot program in the UK to replace counterfeit versions of Windows XP with legitimate ones, targeting users who purchased PCs with pre-installed copies of the operating system before November. The company aims to detect illegal traders and transform users of fake Windows versions into legitimate ones. The Windows XP Counterfeit Project offers free replacement for counterfeit software until the end of the year, subject to certain conditions. The pilot program aims to gather information about illegal traders and the authenticity of Windows XP software. The company intends to evaluate the program's results in the UK before implementing similar schemes in other countries.

Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced new measures targeting elderly citizens and homebuyers in the Labour Party's election campaign. The level for paying stamp duty has doubled to £120,000 for homebuyers, and pensioners will be given a one-off council tax refund of £200. Child tax credit will increase with earnings, while personal income tax allowance will only rise in line with inflation. Brown has also increased taxes on beer, wine, and cigarettes. However, petrol duty will remain frozen until September. The Conservatives criticized the budget, while the Liberal Democrats accused it of being insufficient. Brown defended his budget, stating it balanced affordability, investment, and stability. Additionally, the chancellor announced plans to commemorate the Queen Mother and equal tax status for same-sex couples.

Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby" won several top awards, including Best Picture at the Oscars. Eastwood also won Best Director, beating Martin Scorsese, who was nominated for "The Aviator." Hilary Swank and Morgan Freeman won acting awards for their performances in "Million Dollar Baby," while Cate Blanchett won Best Supporting Actress for her role in "The Aviator." Jamie Foxx won Best Actor for his portrayal of Ray Charles in "Ray." Other winners included "The Incredibles" for Best Animated Feature, "Sideways" for Best Adapted Screenplay, and "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" for Best Original Screenplay. Comedian Chris Rock hosted the ceremony for the first time.

Valve, the game maker of Half-Life 2, has banned around 20,000 players from using the game due to evidence that their copy was obtained illegally. Valve created an anti-piracy system for the game, which required players to authenticate their copy online before playing. The system checks which copy of the game is being run and helped identify who had obtained pirated copies of the game. Valve also revealed that a small number of accounts were closed because people were using stolen credit cards to buy copies of the game. Some who have been banned from the game have protested their innocence, but the move proves the power of the Steam system in combating piracy. Experts suggest that other game makers may be tempted to create their own anti-piracy systems if Valve's proves successful, but warn that consumers may tire of maintaining different accounts for every game.

Roxy Music on Isle of Wight bill Roxy Music will appear at June's Isle of Wight music festival, along with Morrissey, Supergrass and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from 10-12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzerana, Andy Mackay and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band are also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music were formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's Virginia Plain, with other hits including Street Life, Love Is The Drug and the 1981 John Lennon cover, Jealous Guy. Roxy Music's back catalogue was re-released in 2000, leading to the band undertaking a world tour in 2001. Morrissey will also play on Saturday at the festival, while Supergrass and Idlewild have been confirmed for the Friday.

In the DVD review, the movie "I, Robot" is described as an action-packed thriller with Will Smith and CGI robots. While it may not leave a lasting impression, it is enjoyable to watch and includes extras such as commentaries and a making-of feature. The review also discusses the movie "King Arthur," which is entertaining despite its inaccuracies. The battle scenes are well done and the behind-the-scenes extras are interesting. The BBC series "British Isles" is surprisingly intriguing, despite initial expectations that it would be light and fluffy due to the presence of host Alan Titchmarsh. Titchmarsh proves to be knowledgeable about the subject matter, and the show provides a fascinating look at the history of the British landscape.

The UK needs a change of direction to compete with other countries and prosper, according to Oliver Letwin, the shadow chancellor of the Tory Party. In a speech at their spring conference, Letwin promised £4bn tax cuts, claiming that the burden of regulation and tax on the economy hinders the country's ability to tackle economic challenges. The Tory co-chairman, Liam Fox, criticised Labour's record on issues such as immigration and education, and Michael Howard was due to address the conference, but had to postpone due to his involvement in opposing the Prevention of Terrorism Bill. Tony Blair has accused Conservative policies of causing economic failure.

Although phone sales have increased due to the popularity of phones equipped with cameras and color screens, not many people are taking advantage of the multimedia capabilities. Research shows that many UK camera phone users haven't sent any multimedia messages despite camera phone sales doubling. Phone companies are trying to educate people on how to use the multimedia capabilities and make the interfaces more user-friendly. People's apprehension is compounded by concerns about the interoperability of multimedia across networks and different kinds of phones, and limitations on the number of messages that can be sent at any given time. However, there are solutions, such as broadcast technology, that enable operators to get multimedia content to customers faster and in better quality.

Heineken and Carlsberg, two of the biggest breweries in the world, have reported a drop in profits due to declining beer sales in western Europe. Heineken's profits dropped 33% in 2004 and may continue to decline in 2005, while Carlsberg saw a 3% fall in profits due to lower demand and higher marketing costs. Future growth is expected from the Russian and Chinese markets as western European markets are mostly mature. Heineken's revenue improved despite the dip in profits, and it plans to invest 100m euros in aggressive marketing while also looking to cut costs. Carlsberg's profits are projected to rise by 15% in 2005, but the company is cutting jobs in Sweden due to declining sales. Investment bank Merrill Lynch remains cautious about the outlook for revenue growth across western Europe.

MPs are scheduled to interrogate high-ranking officials at the Duchy of Lancaster and Duchy of Cornwall regarding the royals' private income. The aides are expected to appear before the Commons Public Accounts Committee, but reports suggest that they might not have an idea of how Prince Charles' expenditures on Camilla Parker Bowles are being funded. They're not accountable for the money's use, as their responsibility is to create income. The Duchy of Lancaster generates the Queen's private income, while the Duchy of Cornwall supports Prince Charles' yearly income. The latter has an estate spanning across 25 counties, including residential properties, stocks, and shares, founded by King Edward III in 1337 to provide income to the heirs of the throne. It finances the prince's personal and public life, and neither he nor his children receive taxpayers' money from the Civil List. Yet, the prince was granted over £4m from government departments and grants-in-aid in 2003-4, and the Duchy produced almost £12m in revenue in the previous year. Since 1993, the Prince of Wales has been voluntarily submitting 40% income tax.

Jonny Wilkinson is unlikely to play in the 2005 RBS Six Nations due to his latest injury. His club coach, Rob Andrew, stated that even though Wilkinson had hoped to recover in time, it would be irresponsible to put him straight into a Test match, with only two games left to play. Wilkinson is aiming to return for his club, Newcastle, on March 13th, but Andrew said it is touch and go whether he will be ready. The coach emphasized that they cannot afford to get it wrong with a knee injury and that Wilkinson would need to be reintroduced to playing gradually. Although he has not played for England since the 2003 World Cup final, Wilkinson hopes to be selected for the Lions tour to New Zealand this summer, but the Lions coach has not set a deadline for his return.

Real experts have identified that the success of the TV show CSI has given people unrealistic expectations of forensic science. This has resulted in a significant increase in evidence submitted to forensic labs, causing large backlogs. Jurors are also affected because they have a distorted view of how forensic evidence is used. A science conference in Washington D.C. addressed the issue. While the show has had some positive effects, the negative effects on the field have caused concerns for scientists, investigators, and lawyers alike. There is a need for better funding of forensic science at the university level.

The Conservative party has accused Labour of using a White Paper on the EU to mislead the British public ahead of the referendum on the EU constitution. The Shadow Foreign Secretary, Michael Ancram, claimed that the White Paper was designed to soften public opinion in favour of the constitution, and was a “taxpayer subsidised propaganda exercise.” The Foreign Secretary, Jack Straw, dismissed the accusations and argued that cooperation with the EU could result in better immigration controls for the UK. In a parliamentary debate, Straw launched the White Paper, which outlined three key themes of security, stability, and prosperity during the UK’s chairmanship of the EU from July 2005. The Electoral Commission said the proposed referendum question is clear, despite concerns raised by MPs. The referendum is likely to take place in spring 2006, while the Conservative party will campaign for a “no” vote.

The BBC has written an article about how mobile games have evolved, and they provide reviews of some popular games that can be downloaded onto mobile phones. There is a demand for mobile games from commuters, game fans, and hardcore gamers, and the market has become very lucrative. Over 200 different games are available for download on some UK networks, including ports of classic PC and arcade games, action films with tie-ins, and unique games only found on handsets. The technology in phones has improved, allowing for more sophisticated games with better graphics, physics, and the ability to compete against other players in real-time or using Bluetooth technology. The article discusses some popular games available for download, such as Too Fast Too Furious and Fatal Force.

The 2D version of Metal Slug 3 offers a fun, old-school experience for gamers. It stands out among modern games that focus on visual appeal, with its hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling gameplay. It offers a challenging and fast-paced shooter experience, with players battling a variety of enemies, including giant bosses, and piloting various vehicles. While it may not have the same graphics as modern games, it provides a refreshing change from the lack of innovation seen in many modern blockbuster titles. Players who enjoy a tough challenge will appreciate the game's difficulty, but its addictive gameplay will have them coming back for more. At the low price of £20, it is a great value for those seeking a nostalgic, retro-style gaming experience.

Lufthansa, the German airline, has generated a positive financial outcome for the year 2004, after experiencing significant losses in the previous year. The preliminary report highlighted that the airline recorded net profits of 400 million euros, up from a loss of 984 million euros in 2003. The operating profits in 2004 were ten times higher than 2003, reaching 380 million euros. The airline suffered a decline in demand and competition in 2003 because of the Iraq war and SARS. They were also negatively impacted by issues at their United States catering business. Although other European and American airlines were on the verge of bankruptcy last year, Lufthansa started to recover. The company's board recommends paying shareholders a dividend of 0.30 euros per share in 2004. The complete results of their financial performance will be disclosed on the 23rd of March.

A meeting about the future of Gibraltar will take place over two days at Jack Straw's residence in Kent. The summit aims to establish a new forum for discussing the Rock's future, following an agreement made by Mr Straw and his Spanish counterpart in October. The forum would give Gibraltarians a say in their future, after a majority voted to remain British in a referendum. Gibraltar's Chief Minister, Peter Caruana, and Britain's Europe Director, Dominick Chilcott, will represent the UK, while Spain will be represented by their director general for Europe, Jose Maria Pons. This initiative from Spain comes after their government put their sovereignty ambitions on hold, as Gibraltarians rejected plans for shared sovereignty in a previous referendum.

The Scottish Parliament is set to decide whether Westminster should have the power to legislate on super-casinos in the UK. The government plans to build up to eight Las Vegas-style resorts in the country, with one likely to be in Glasgow. While Scottish ministers claim they will have the final say on the matter, opposition parties argue this won't be the case in practice. The vote, which is expected to be close, will take place on Wednesday. The new law will address internet gambling for the first time and aim to prevent minors from participating. A potential location for a super-casino in Glasgow could be either Ibrox or the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre. The Scottish National Party and the Conservatives believe the issue of super-casinos should be decided in Scotland, while the Scottish Executive believes it should be handled by Westminster.

Laura Ashley's CEO, Ainum Mohd-Saaid, is resigning for personal reasons, effective from February 1st. This follows the departure of the co-CEO, Rebecca Navarednam, on January 1st. Lillian Tan, a non-executive director and head of a Malaysian retailer, will be replacing Ms. Mohd-Saaid. The company has recently been struggling with poor sales, particularly in the clothing sector. Laura Ashley is majority-owned by Malaysia entrepreneur Dr. Khoo Kay Peng, who denies intentions to take the company private. The company has been focusing on home furnishings over clothing, and its shares were down 8.51% in late morning trading on the London Stock Exchange. Laura Ashley has thanked Ms. Mohd-Saaid for her services to the company.

Stuart Pearce, the joint assistant boss at Manchester City, has expressed his desire to become the manager of the club after Kevin Keegan steps down in 18 months. Pearce has been with the club since 2001 as a player and then as a coach, and was promoted to joint assistant manager when Arthur Cox left last summer. Although he has previously been linked with other job opportunities, Pearce is said to want to wait for his chance at City, hoping that the board deems him good enough for the role.

McClaren eyes Uefa Cup top spot Steve McClaren wants his Middlesbrough team to win their Uefa Cup group by beating Partizan Belgrade. Boro have already qualified for the knockout stages alongside Partizan and Villareal, at the expense of Lazio. But boss McClaren is looking for a victory which would mean they avoid a team that has played in the Champions League in Friday's third-round draw. "To need a win to finish top is fantastic, but it is going to be a tough one," McClaren said. "When the draw was made, I thought it was the toughest group of them all - and so it has proved. "Lazio were favourites, Villarreal have been semi-finalists, and Partizan have fantastic experience in Europe. "The pleasing thing is we did the business in the first two games. "Winning those two has put us in a great position and it has been a fantastic experience playing these teams."

The BBC is planning on spending £9m on producing new comedy and entertainment shows outside of London, as part of a strategy to appeal to a wider audience. The factual and daytime departments outside of London will also be restructured, with new roles being created to help develop shows with independent production companies. The new head of comedy commissioning, based in Glasgow, will be in charge of the budget, and will work with independent companies to produce new shows. Similar roles will also be created in Bristol and Birmingham for other departments. The aim is to create a strong independent production base and competition to deliver the best ideas to the audience. Jana Bennett, the Director of Television, says the changes will ensure that the best ideas are brought to the screen efficiently and effectively.

Stan Lee, the respected comic book writer, is teaming up with movie producer Robert Evans to create a new superhero film called "Foreverman". The movie will center around a character who has to handle everyday life problems in addition to saving the world with their unique abilities. Although there is not much information about the project, Paramount Pictures has hinted that it has the potential to spawn a series of films. Lee is well-known for his work on Spider-Man and The Incredible Hulk, and is working with screenwriter Peter Briggs on the script. Lee's aim is to create an original concept that can become an evergreen franchise for Paramount. Many of Lee's previous comic book creations, such as X-Men and Daredevil, have been turned into films, but Spider-Man has been the most successful, grossing almost $1.6bn worldwide. The Fantastic Four, another Marvel Comics adaptation, will be released in cinemas this summer.

Tony Blair has denied the claim that he promised Gordon Brown he would resign before the next general election. According to the book, Brown's Britain, published in The Sunday Telegraph, Tony Blair promised to make way for Gordon Brown but then broke his promise when Cabinet allies intervened in June 2004. Tony Blair called these claims "reheated" from six months ago and that both of them were focusing on the issues that concern the country. The book claimed that the two had mutual animosity and contempt for each other. There has been speculation of a rift after their separate responses to the Asian tsunami. Tony Blair denied the rumors and called them a "load of nonsense." The Prime Minister stated that he and Brown were concentrating on running the country, tackling issues such as the Asian tsunami disaster, the Middle East peace process, and Northern Ireland, and played down the alleged rift between them.

Carlos Moya has decided not to participate in the Davis Cup in 2005 in order to focus on the Grand Slams. Despite leading Spain to victory over the USA in the previous year, Moya wants to concentrate on his career goals and come into the major events in top form. He plans to return to the Davis Cup team in 2006, and has been working on his physical and technical condition to ensure he performs well in the significant tournaments of the year.

Marcel Desailly believes that Chelsea will have a different outcome when they face Barcelona in the Champions League on Wednesday, compared to the 2000 quarter-final second leg, where they were defeated 5-1 at the Nou Camp. Desailly argues that Chelsea has improved significantly, and their players are mentally stronger, thanks to a new motivation and a different mentality. The former Chelsea captain thinks that pressure will be on Barcelona as Chelsea is now one of the major clubs in Europe. Despite winding down his career in Qatar, Desailly still holds admiration for his former colleagues from AC Milan, Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta, who are likely to play against Manchester United.

The CEO of Texas Instruments, Rich Templeton, believes that Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) is a growing sector and will be the next major application to drive broadband connections into homes. Internet service provider Wanadoo is launching its own broadband telephony service in the UK, allowing subscribers to make free evening and weekend calls to any UK landline and free calls at any time to other Wanadoo users for an additional cost of £4 a month. Wanadoo aims to replace existing landline services and to provide video-on-demand and home security services. The CEO of Wanadoo believes that VoIP is going to have a dramatic impact on the telecommunications industry. The world's largest chip maker for mobile phones believes that the VoIP technology will grow rapidly, and it has already downloaded 83 million people that powered the Skype VoIP service. Giant ISP AOL plans to launch a net-based phone service for some of its members within a month. Customers will continue to use their traditional phones, but they will plug them into adapters connected to their broadband source rather than the jack provided by the telephone company.

The original members of the popular Swedish pop group Abba have come together for the first time in nearly two decades to attend the premiere of the hit musical, Mamma Mia!, which features their songs. One of the members, Agnetha Fältskog, who has been reclusive since the band disbanded in 1982 also made a public appearance. The musical will be performed in Swedish for the first time and the translation of the musical was overseen by Bjorn Ulvaeus, a former Abba member. The show has become a worldwide phenomenon and has been staged in several countries including the UK and the US, and has been watched by over 20 million people.

Robots march to US cinema summit Animated movie Robots has opened at the top of the US and Canada box office chart, taking $36.5m (£19m) on its first weekend on release. Featuring the voices of Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams and Mel Brooks, Robots follows a robot inventor who moves to a big city. Vin Diesel's family comedy The Pacifier fell to the number two spot, taking $18.1m (£9.4m). New Bruce Willis movie Hostage opened at number four with $9.8m (£5.1m). However, a recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, which featured less violence than last year's original movie, took just $239,850 (£125,000), despite opening in 957 cinemas. The new version of the film received little publicity and the original version is available across the US on DVD. "We certainly had higher expectations than what we got," said Rob Schwartz, head of distribution for Newmarket Films, which released The Passion of the Christ. "We were trying to get the film out there, hoping it would reach an audience that it didn't quite reach the first time around. It doesn't seem to have worked out quite as well as we had hoped." Meanwhile, Will Smith comedy Hitch has become the top film at the global box office after taking an estimated $30.1m (£15.6m) over the weekend at cinemas outside North America, according to industry website Screen Daily. It has taken $65.5m (£34.1m) so far, buoyed by opening at number one in the UK last weekend and a successful run in Germany. The movie, which cost a reported $70m (£36.4m) to make, has taken $138m (£72m) in the US so far.

Technology companies like Sony, Philips, Matsushita, and Samsung are collaborating to develop a common way to prevent digital music and video piracy. They want to create a system that ensures files can only be played on the hardware they produce and prevent illegal copying. However, this move may lead to more confusion for consumers who are already struggling with various content control systems. These systems are known as Digital Rights Management (DRM) and limit what people can do with their downloaded files. The Marlin Joint Development Association is the alliance set up by the four firms to work on this common control system. The system will define basic specifications that every device made by the four companies will conform to. The move is a way for the companies to decide their fate on content control instead of having to rely on Microsoft and Apple. However, this new common system will sit alongside the existing content control systems of rival companies such as Apple and Microsoft, which could cause more confusion. DRM systems are meant to control consumers, and firms use them to maximize profit. There are doubts about the Marlin system's ability to achieve its goal since no DRM system has managed to prevent piracy. DRM systems only control the consumers, so the studios and labels can sell their media again and again to maximize profits.

The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is taking place in Las Vegas and is showcasing new technologies and gadgets that will be available in the coming year. There will be over 50,000 new products unveiled during the show, including the next generation Xbox, which will be announced in a pre-show keynote speech by Microsoft Chief, Bill Gates. The focus of this year's show will be on technologies that allow people to control their multimedia content and watch it anytime, anywhere. Digital technology in 2004 showed the strongest growth yet in the US, and it is predicted to continue in 2005 with wholesale shipments expected to rise by 11%. The CEA predicts that there will be several key technology trends to watch such as gaming on mobile devices and the increase in hard drive boxes capable of storing thousands of images, video and audio files that can be accessed through other devices within a home network.

Kenenisa Bekele, who has won the Olympic 10,000m race, is determined to break the world indoor two-mile record at the upcoming Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham. The record is currently held by his mentor Haile Gebrselassie, who set it at the same event in 2003. Kenenisa has previously broken the world indoor 5,000m record at the same venue. He will be racing against other athletes, including his compatriots Mulugeta Wondimu, Abiyote Abate, and Markos Geneti. The event has also attracted other Olympic champions such as Kelly Holmes, Jason Gardener, and Mark Lewis-Francis.

Researchers are working to develop more powerful laptop batteries that can last for an entire working day without needing to be charged. This involves creating new chemical mixtures for batteries and implementing changes in the production of laptop components, as well as reducing the power consumed by displays. Lithium-ion battery technology has already been maximized, so other changes are necessary to achieve the goal of laptops lasting up to eight hours on a single charge. The establishment of the Mobile PC Extended Battery Life (EBL) Working Group has allowed industry players to share information about creating less power-hungry notebooks. Intel's work in testing energy consumption of laptop components has led to improvements in reducing power usage. Efforts are also focused on developing displays that consume less energy. Ultimately, achieving a laptop battery life of eight hours is a valuable goal for the industry to strive for.

Gordon Brown's top adviser, Ed Balls, has denied rumors of a pre-election spending spree in the upcoming budget.
