He stated that the Chancellor of the Exchequer would abide by his fiscal rules and not engage in pre-election bribery. Sir Digby Jones, Director General of the CBI, echoed Balls' sentiment, asserting that any extra money should go toward improving worker skillsets rather than public expenditures. Balls also addressed the potential impact of an expected rise in interest rates on Labour's electoral chances but downplayed its significance. Overall, both Balls and Sir Digby emphasized the importance of stability in the economy, with Balls assuring that the Chancellor's budget would not jeopardize it.

The SAP Open in San Jose will see American top seed and defending champion Andy Roddick face Cyril Saulnier in the final on Sunday. Roddick beat Germany's Tommy Haas in a 7-6 (7-3) 6-3 win, while Saulnier overcame seventh seed Jurgen Melzer 6-7 (3-7) 6-3 6-3, who suffered an ankle injury early in the second set. The win sees Saulnier break into the world's top 50 for the first time, which he attributes to hard work and a strong mindset. Despite being broken at the start of the second set, Roddick broke back and again to lead 4-2, frustrating Haas who missed opportunities to win points.

Tony Blair has announced that the Commission for Africa's report will be released on March 11th, which is Comic Relief day. The report will be used as a basis for talks on Africa during the G8 summit in July chaired by Prime Minister Blair. The commission includes Bob Geldof and has addressed issues such as more aid, fairer trade, less debt, and corruption in Africa. Blair hopes the report will be "brutally frank about the reality" but "idealistic about what can be done." He also acknowledges the need to persuade other nations to commit to debt relief. The commission will deliver new thinking to change direction for Africa and includes African government leaders, other politicians, and experts from developed countries.

TV future in the hands of viewers With home theatre systems, plasma high-definition TVs, and digital video recorders moving into the living room, the way people watch TV will be radically different in five years' time. That is according to an expert panel which gathered at the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas to discuss how these new technologies will impact one of our favourite pastimes. With the US leading the trend, programmes and other content will be delivered to viewers via home networks, through cable, satellite, telecoms companies, and broadband service providers to front rooms and portable devices. One of the most talked-about technologies of CES has been digital and personal video recorders (DVR and PVR). These set-top boxes, like the US's TiVo and the UK's Sky+ system, allow people to record, store, play, pause and forward wind TV programmes when they want. Essentially, the technology allows for much more personalised TV. They are also being built-in to high-definition TV sets, which are big business in Japan and the US, but slower to take off in Europe because of the lack of high-definition programming. Not only can people forward wind through adverts, they can also forget about abiding by network and channel schedules, putting together their own a-la-carte entertainment. But some US networks and cable and satellite companies are worried about what it means for them in terms of advertising revenues as well as "brand identity" and viewer loyalty to channels. Although the US leads in this technology at the moment, it is also a concern that is being raised in Europe, particularly with the growing uptake of services like Sky+. "What happens here today, we will see in nine months to a years' time in the UK," Adam Hume, the BBC Broadcast's futurologist told the BBC News website. For the likes of the BBC, there are no issues of lost advertising revenue yet. It is a more pressing issue at the moment for commercial UK broadcasters, but brand loyalty is important for everyone. "We will be talking more about content brands rather than network brands," said Tim Hanlon, from brand communications firm Starcom MediaVest. "The reality is that with broadband connections, anybody can be the producer of content." He added: "The challenge now is that it is hard to promote a programme with so much choice." What this means, said Stacey Jolna, senior vice president of TV Guide TV group, is that the way people find the content they want to watch has to be simplified for TV viewers. It means that networks, in US terms, or channels could take a leaf out of Google's book and be the search engine of the future, instead of the scheduler to help people find what they want to watch. This kind of channel model might work for the younger iPod generation which is used to taking control of their gadgets and what they play on them. But it might not suit everyone, the panel recognised. Older generations are more comfortable with familiar schedules and channel brands because they know what they are getting. They perhaps do not want so much of the choice put into their hands, Mr Hanlon suggested. "On the other end, you have the kids just out of diapers who are pushing buttons already - everything is possible and available to them," said Mr Hanlon. "Ultimately, the consumer will tell the market they want." Of the 50,000 new gadgets and technologies being showcased at CES, many of them are about enhancing the TV-watching experience. High-definition TV sets are everywhere and many new models of LCD (Liquid Crystal Display) TVs have been launched with DVR capability built into them, instead of being external boxes. One such example launched at the show is Humax's 26-inch LCD TV with an 80-hour TiVo DVR and DVD recorder. One of the US's biggest satellite TV companies, DirectTV, has even launched its own branded DVR at the show with 100-hours of recording capability, instant replay, and a search function. The set can pause and rewind TV for up to 90 hours. And Microsoft chief Bill Gates announced in his pre-show keynote speech a partnership with TiVo, called TiVoToGo, which means people can play recorded programmes on Windows PCs and mobile devices. All these reflect the increasing trend of freeing up multimedia so that people can watch what they want, when they want.

According to recent figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS), UK retail sales were better than anticipated in November, with a rise of 0.6% on the month and 6.1% on the year. This positive news for retailers could be attributed to the seasonal increase in Christmas shopping, along with aggressive discounting strategies implemented by brands such as Marks & Spencer. However, recent data from the British Retail Consortium showed a slight slip of 0.2% in High Street sales during November. Despite the uncertainty caused by this mixed data, the report fueled a rally for the sterling and suggests that a further interest rate rise could happen in the New Year.

Wal-Mart, the biggest retailer in the world, has agreed to pay $14.5m (£7.74m) to settle a lawsuit that involved thousands of gun sales breaches in California between 2000 and 2003. The settlement, which includes $5m in fines and more than $4m to fund compliance checks with gun regulation and to prevent the sale of ammunition to minors, was announced after the company suspended firearms sales in California. The lawsuit accused Wal-Mart of selling firearms to people who weren't allowed to own them and delivering guns to customers who bought them for prohibited persons. Although the company has not announced any plans to restart firearms sales in California, Bill Lockyer, California attorney general, stated that the supermarket chain must follow state regulations if it were to do so.

After the tsunami disaster in Asia, text messaging technology proved to be a useful communication tool, as it can get through when cell phone signals are too weak for a spoken conversation. Sanjaya Senanayake, or Morquendi, was one of the first to use this method, providing ground assessments of needs through text messages that were shared on a blog called Dogs without Borders. Taran Rampersad in Trinidad and Tobago saw the potential for centralizing text messages and redistributing them to aid workers or other people who could help. He, along with Dan Lane and other techies, are creating the Alert Retrieval Cache, an open-source system to link those in need with those who can help. However, creating awareness about the system's availability remains a significant challenge. Rampersad hopes that governments will eventually take notice and support the Alert Retrieval Cache.

The Liberal Democrats are advocating for increased protection for people susceptible to problem debt. They argue that banks are aggressively promoting financial products, and as a result, one in eight households already struggle with debt. The Lib Dems' Treasury spokesman is unveiling policy proposals aimed at tackling this issue, which include implementing "proper health checks" when loans are marketed to ensure people are aware of payment protection options. Vincent Cable, the Lib Dems' spokesperson, warns that if economic conditions worsen, a significant number of people could be affected because they have already borrowed up to their limit. Additionally, Mr. Cable believes that some of the payment protection currently available is "extremely expensive" with "lots of exclusions." The Liberal Democrats are campaigning to be seen as the "real opposition" ahead of the next general election. They argue that, in northern cities, the race is between them and Labour, while in Southern seats, particularly southwest, it is between them and the Tories.

Labour Party members, including Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, were criticized by MPs during a meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party due to reports of a feud between the two men that could harm the party's election chances. Despite a new book claiming that Blair had upset Brown by not standing aside, the PM assured members that the party's campaign wouldn't be affected. Brown was set to attend an event intended to show party unity but reports suggest his relationship with Alan Milburn, who is running Labour's election campaign, has been tense since Blair brought him back into the Cabinet. Some MPs threatened to expose those behind the feud if it didn't stop, while Lord Campbell-Savours challenged Brown to deny claims that he didn't believe anything Blair said. The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats criticized the pair for obstructing good government due to personal ambition.

It is predicted that ticket sales at the US box office will break records this year, reaching $9.4 billion, which is higher than the all-time high in 2002. However, the lack of a Christmas blockbuster like last year's Lord of the Rings may affect the overall figures. While the number of admissions has decreased, the expected record is due to the increase in ticket prices. Despite big hits like The Passion of the Christ and Fahrenheit 9/11 coming from outside major studios, Sony Pictures is expected to top the domestic market share. The trend for Hollywood studios is to invest in the upper and lower ends of the market and ignore the middle.

The head of the World Anti-Doping Agency, Dick Pound, has stated that if Marion Jones is found guilty of taking banned substances, she must be stripped of all her medals and banned from competing for two years. The allegations were made by Victor Conte, who claims that Jones regularly used drugs to enhance her performance. The International Olympic Committee has a rule that athletes can only be stripped of their medals if caught within three years of the event. Jones, who won five medals at the 2000 Olympics, denies using drugs and plans to take legal action. The investigation into doping in the US is centered around the Balco Laboratories firm. Pound believes that Jones' alleged drug use would be disappointing for many people.

Spending on credit and debit cards has exceeded cash spending in the UK for the first time. According to the Association for Payment Clearing Services, the moment that plastic surpassed cash occurred at 10.38am on Wednesday. A school teacher named Helen Carroll was chosen to make the historic transaction, paying for her groceries in a Tesco's supermarket branch. Mrs. Carroll usually makes most of her payments with her debit card and occasionally uses her credit cards. Apacs predicts that shoppers in the UK will put £269bn on plastic cards during 2004, compared to £268bn paid with cash. The introduction of debit cards, accounting for two-thirds of plastic card transactions, has been the main driver in the popularity of plastic, providing added security and flexibility.

The World Community Grid, recently launched, allows individuals to donate the idle processing power of their computers to help solve health and social problems. The grid uses donated processor cycles to create virtual supercomputers that will tackle the most difficult issues. Similar projects, like Seti@home, have already achieved success with untapped processing power from millions of desktop PCs. Volunteers can download a special screensaver from the WCG website to donate their spare time. The grid is set up to tackle up to six projects each year, selected by an international advisory board of experts in health sciences and technology. IBM has donated the necessary infrastructure to build the grid, similar to the Smallpox Research Grid created with United Devices. The Human Proteome Folding Project is the first undertaking, aiming to identify the ways proteins in our body fold.

Fans who purchase tickets for this year's Glastonbury festival will be provided with a photo ID card in an effort to prevent tickets from being resold by touts, according to festival organiser Michael Eavis. The ID card will contain a picture of the ticket-holder, along with electronic chip details, to authenticate ticket validity.  The event's rising popularity has meant a high demand for tickets, with over 153,000 people expected to attend from 24-26 June. The ID card proposition has been described as a significant step in terms of event ticketing control, but Eavis' daughter Emily Eavis hopes it will work if approached properly.

Flanker Colin Charvis is set to miss the last two Six Nations games for Wales due to an ankle injury. Despite his efforts to recover, Wales physio Mark Davies doesn't believe he will feature in the game against Scotland and is doubtful for the final game. Centre Sonny Parker is also unlikely to play due to a neck injury, but Hal Luscombe is fit for the upcoming match. Replacement hooker Robin McBryde is uncertain to play due to a knee ligament injury, and Steve Jones from the Dragons is expected to take his place if necessary. The return of Luscombe offers Wales more options and depth, according to assistant coach Scott Johnson.

Actress Nicole Kidman has obtained a restraining order against two paparazzi photographers who she claims caused her to fear for her safety and feel threatened. This comes after a bugging device was found outside her Sydney home, and an incident where paparazzi reportedly chased her vehicle through red lights and the wrong side of the road. Kidman acknowledges photographers have a job to do, but these actions were specific to these individuals, causing her to feel unable to leave her home safely. Magistrate Lee Gilmore issued the restraining order, saying that while photographers are entitled to earn a living, their behavior must have limits.

The UK government has proposed a new anti-terrorism bill, which includes the power for the Home Secretary to put suspects under house arrest without trial. The bill has faced opposition from the Conservative, Liberal Democrat and some Labour MPs, who believe judges should be the only ones with the power to order detention of UK citizens. The bill proposes "control orders", which would allow for house arrest in extreme cases, as well as curfews and limits on phone and internet access for other suspects. The opposition parties are concerned that the home secretary would have too much power, rather than granting judges more responsibility. The current laws, which detain foreign terror suspects, have been ruled to break human rights rules, and the new bill plans to replace them. The controversy surrounding the bill is whether politicians should have the power to detain UK citizens without trial or whether it takes away their civil liberties. Although the government is expected to win the vote in the House of Commons, they will face strong opposition in the House of Lords.

The number of people without jobs in Germany increased in December, marking the 11th consecutive month of rising unemployment. The average number of jobless people throughout the year reached its highest level since 1990 due to bad weather and a sluggish economy, with the total standing at 4.483 million. While 2004 saw the end of three years of economic stagnation, the upturn in fortunes was not enough to stimulate the labour market, according to labour office chief, Frank-Juergen Weise. The introduction of government welfare reforms is also expected to increase unemployment levels further in the coming months, although the Hartz IV reforms could help cut the average jobless rate in the longer term.

Two major trade unions in the UK, Amicus and the Transport and General Workers Union (TGWU), are considering merging to create a "super union" with two million members. The purpose of the merger is to increase their influence with government officials and employers. Approval from the unions' executives and members would be necessary for any merger to take place. Confidential meetings will be held on Wednesday to discuss the proposal, although both unions have not confirmed or denied the rumors. The Warwick Agreement was a 56-point deal made between the Labour Party's leadership and Amicus, the TGWU, GMB, and Unison, which focused on equal rights in the workplace, holidays, and pensions.

The plan to create a single correctional agency in Scotland by merging the Scottish Prison Service with local authority social work criminal justice departments has been abandoned due to opposition. Instead, there will be closer collaboration between Scottish councils and the prison service to reduce reoffending rates, which are high in Scotland. The new measures will entail a statutory duty on the SPS to partner with local authorities and an advisory board to assist the justice minister in reducing reoffending rates. The objective is to provide more accountability to the public, parliament, and ministers.

Experts are predicting a potential shortage of popular gadgets this Christmas, with Apple's iPod being a top item on many wish lists. The editor of Stuff magazine suggests that the iPod mini may be hard to come by, similar to the popular toy Tracey Island in previous years. However, there will be a gadget show in London showcasing the latest technology and gadgets, including Sony's Qrio Robot and a virtual keyboard. MP3 players remain the most popular stocking stuffer, with the Gizmondo being a powerful gaming console that doubles as an MP3 player, movie player, and camera. Gadgets are now considered lifestyle products that women are also interested in, rather than just for tech enthusiasts.

The latest annual register of members' interests shows the significant earnings that former politicians can make after leaving front-bench politics. William Hague, former Tory leader, earned up to £820,000 on top of his MPs' salary through speaking fees and two one-man shows. Michael Portillo, former shadow chancellor, makes up to £560,000 a year, partially from speeches and TV work. Other former politicians, such as Alan Milburn and Robin Cook, also earned significant amounts from speeches, articles, and advisory work. The register shows incomes in bands of £5,000, making it difficult to calculate exact earnings.

The economies of Southern Asia have been severely impacted by the massive earthquake and waves that hit the region, with Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand being the worst affected. The World Bank has estimated that aid of around $5 billion will be required to help the region, with tourism being a critical part of the economy. However, many industries have been damaged, including fishing and farming, with hundreds of thousands of buildings and small boats destroyed by the waves. Several organizations have pledged aid to help, with the United Nations emergency relief coordinator warning that the disaster may be the worst national disaster in recent history. Insurers are also struggling to assess the damage, with some stating that the bill may be less than the $27bn cost of the hurricanes that hit the US earlier in the year. Despite the potential financial impact, the severity of the disaster has been underlined, with many regions experiencing long-term damage to their economies and communities.

Labour's leaders showed a united front during a campaign poster launch, despite reports of a rift between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown causing concern among some MPs. The launch saw Alan Milburn, who controversially took over election planning from Brown, share a platform with the chancellor for the first time. MPs reportedly warned that feuding between the prime minister and chancellor could harm Labour's election success at a private meeting on Monday. The event came after a new book exposed disputes between Blair and Brown. The launch focused on the party's record on the economy, which Brown said demonstrated the public's trust in Labour's ability to manage the country's finances. However, Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox criticised the display of unity, and argued the party had broken several promises while in government.

Aston Villa manager, David O'Leary, has agreed on a new three-and-a-half year contract extension, securing his place at the club until the summer of 2008. There were rumours in December that O'Leary would leave if he didn't receive a new contract, but he denied them and said he is committed to the challenge of improving Villa's overall performance. O'Leary wants to see Aston Villa rank within the top six teams in the Premiership consistently, but acknowledges they need quality players to achieve that. He also emphasized the importance of retaining his right-hand men, Roy Aitken and Steve McGregor, and getting their contracts sorted simultaneously. The Villa chairman, Doug Ellis, expressed his happiness at keeping O'Leary, citing his excellent performance since joining the club in 2003. Additionally, O'Leary has criticized the team's captain, Olof Mellberg, for making comments ahead of a match against rivals Birmingham and has cautioned him against leaving himself open to criticism.

The Four-Kings clan in the UK is organizing a tournament that offers a prize of $1m, and it is seeking new players to take on the world's best in the Painkiller game. The qualifiers are open to anyone who can register on the Four-Kings, Jolt.co.uk, and Painkiller tournament websites before 12 November. Online qualifiers will be held from 16-28 November to find the best eight players, with the top players signing up for a contract with the Four-Kings team. The Bloodline Tournament on the 3-5 December in London will feature the best two players who will represent the UK at the Cyberathlete Professional League $1m Painkiller contest taking place throughout 2005. The top prize for each contest stop on the world tour is $15,000, with $150,000 awarded to the Grand Final winner in December 2005. Travel expenses for the tour will be paid by Four-Kings for the two UK players who make it to the world tour. The event will be filmed and shared online.

Information regarding the chip in Sony's PlayStation 3 has been disclosed by Sony, IBM, and Toshiba. Referred to as the 'Cell' chip, it is made up of various processing cores and will handle trillions of calculations per second, allowing for extensive graphics and data demands. The three companies have been collaborating on the chip since 2001 and plan to release fuller details about its functions in early 2005. They expect the chip to be approximately 10 times more powerful than current processors and capable of handling up to 16 trillion calculations per second. The first machines to utilize the chip will be computer workstations and servers, with the PlayStation 3 and high-definition TVs following later. A working version of the PlayStation 3 will be demonstrated in May 2005, with official release planned for 2006.

On Friday, Prime Minister Tony Blair surprised staff at HMV in Edinburgh when he walked in accompanied by aides and local police. He purchased two copies of the Band Aid 20 charity single, which is expected to sell at least 300,000 copies by Sunday and is predicted to be this year's Christmas number one. While the single is being sold in many countries across the world, it will not be released in the US. However, US record shops are stocking an import version which is selling well in Los Angeles and New York. Proceeds from the sales will go towards relief for the Darfur region of Sudan and to combat HIV and AIDS across Africa.

Shares across Asian stock markets reached record highs despite the tragedy of the earthquake. Investors did not seem concerned about the impact on listed firms, thinking that the affected areas were too underdeveloped to make much of a difference. Although some economists estimated that Sri Lanka could lose up to 1% of annual growth and Thailand up to 30bn baht in tourism earnings over the next three months, the governments planned to offset this with reconstruction spending. The extent of the overall economic impact of the disaster remained unclear, with many experts pointing out that it was still too soon to tell.

Walter Smith, the new Scotland manager, is determined to restore respect to the national football team. Although qualifying for the 2006 World Cup seems unlikely, Smith wants to end the campaign on a positive note. He believes the team needs to approach each game differently and face the challenge of every match. During a three-day get-together near Manchester, he shared his ideas for improving the team's fortunes with his squad, pointing out that there is no reason for doom and gloom. The squad will train at Manchester United's Carrington complex and Smith will miss the final sessions as he is travelling to Sardinia to watch Italy's friendly with Russia.

SA unveils 'more for all' budget The South African government has put tax cuts and increased social spending at the centre of its latest budget. Aiming to both stir economic growth and aid the country's poor, finance minister Trevor Manuel said the focus of the 2005 budget was "more for all". The tax cuts target firms and individuals, cutting corporate tax from 30% to 29% and offering income tax cuts worth 6.8bn rand ($1.2bn; £910m). Spending on health and education will rise by 9.4% and 8.1% respectively. Spending on housing and sanitation will rise by 12%. All the spending increases will run over the next three years. Unveiling the 418bn-rand budget to parliament, Mr Manuel said the South African economy had grown by an average of 3.2% over the past four years, slightly below the African average of 4%. He predicted that the South African economy would grow by 4.3% in 2005 and 4.2% in 2006. Mr Manuel added that inflation fell to 4.3% in 2004 and is expected to remain at between 3% and 6% from now until at least 2008, helped by interest rates which are at their lowest level in 24 years. Given that both corporate and personal taxes are being cut - under the new measures, those earning less than 35,000 rand a year will be exempt from income tax - the extra 22.3bn rand in social spending will be partly met by higher fuel, tobacco and alcohol taxes. "In this budget, the focus is on more for all, not more for some, and not a hell of a lot more for a few, but spread across all of South Africa," said Mr Manuel. He said that the economic situation was a "marked improvement" on the position at the end of apartheid, but acknowledged that more needed to be done to improve the lives and livelihoods of the disadvantaged. About 280,000 jobs a year have been created in South Africa since 2000 but unemployment remains high, currently close to 30%. Economist Colen Garrow said the budget looked as if it would stimulate economic growth. "It's pleasant to see the cut in company taxes, it's a good incentive for business," he said.

England's Josh Lewsey believes that he was wrongly denied a late try during his team's loss to Ireland in the Six Nations rugby tournament. Lewsey is confident that he touched the ball down over the line and insists that the referee, Jonathan Kaplan, made the wrong decision in disallowing the try. Another player, Mark Cueto, also had a try disallowed and was perplexed as to why it was not allowed. Despite feeling hard done by, they acknowledge that these things happen in the game of rugby.

Voters flock to blog awards site Voting is under way for the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months. Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years, told the BBC News website he was not too surprised by the amount of voters who crowded the site. "The awards always get a lot of traffic; this was just my first year on a server with a bandwidth limit, so I had to guess how much I'd need," he said. There were many new finalists this year, he added, and a few that had won Bloggies before. Several entries reflected specific news events. "There are four nominations for the South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog, which is a pretty timely one for 2005," said Mr Nolan. The big Bloggies battle will be for the ultimate prize of blog of the year. The nominated blogs are wide-ranging covering what is in the news to quirky sites of interest. Fighting it out for the coveted award are Gawker, This Fish Needs a Bicycle, Wonkette, Boing Boing, and Gothamist. In a sign that blogs are playing an increasingly key part in spreading news and current affairs, The South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog is also nominated in the best overall category. GreenFairyDotcom, Londonist, Hicksdesign, PlasticBag and London Underground Tube Blog are the nominees in the best British or Irish weblog. Included in the other categories is best "meme". This is for the top "replicating idea that spread about weblogs". Nominations include Flickr, a web photo album which lets people upload, tag, share and publish their images to blogs. Podcasting has also made an appearance in the category. It is an increasingly popular idea that makes use of RSS (really simple syndication) and audio technology to let people easily make their own radio shows, and distribute them automatically onto portable devices. Many are done by those who already have text-based blogs, so they are almost like audio blogs. Three new categories have been added to the list this year, including best food, best entertainment, and best writing of a weblog. One of the categories that was scrapped though was best music blog. The winners of the fifth annual Bloggies are chosen by the public. Public voting closes on 3 February and the winners will be announced sometime between 13 and 15 March.

Mark Philippoussis may miss the Australian Open due to a groin injury he sustained while playing in a recent tournament. He suffered two tears to the adductor muscle and was unable to play in the mixed doubles. The doctor who treated him believes that it is unlikely he will recover in time for the Open. Although Philippoussis is holding out hope that he can still compete, the injury is serious and he will need time to strengthen his muscles before he can handle the demands of competitive tennis. Another player, Tommy Haas, is also in doubt for the tournament due to a thigh injury he sustained during the same tournament.

The popularity of broadband internet access increased significantly in 2004, with many people signing up due to falling prices and increased marketing. Experts predict that by the end of the next year, over 30% of homes will have broadband access. Local loop unbundling, which would allow competitors to offer faster internet services, became cheaper and more accessible in the UK due to a significant price drop announced by BT. With more than 95% of the population now having broadband access, there are faster broadband options available from cable providers. Nevertheless, understanding broadband plans and deals remains complex for consumers, and broadband is an important technology worth using due to its speed and additional features.

On Thursday, Spanish press reacted to England's 1-0 defeat to Spain, with controversy over racist abuse of England's black players, Wayne Rooney's behaviour and England's poor performance. While there was little coverage of the racist chanting, there was criticism of the English media for stoking up the issue. AS notes the English reaction to Spain coach Luis Aragones' pre-match comments, while Marca focuses on Aragones' praise for his players after the match. Meanwhile, Spain's first-half performance and Xavi's skills were praised, with AS stating that "Spanish football players played better football than the English". Rooney was seen as the worst example of England's poor behaviour, with Gary Neville and Ashley Cole also criticised.

Robert De Niro's film, Hide and Seek, climbed to the top of the North American box office. The movie is a thriller about a widower whose daughter has an eerie imaginary friend. Despite being given mixed reviews by critics, the film surpassed expectations and earned $22 million in ticket sales. Other Oscar-nominated films such as The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby, and Sideways also experienced increased ticket sales. Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby earned $11.8 million during its first weekend of wide release, coming in third place. Despite being in its 15th week of release, Sideways entered the top ten for the first time and landed in seventh place with $6.3 million.  Ice Cube's road-trip comedy "Are We There Yet?" fell to second place after being last week's top film.

The Welsh Health Minister, Jane Hutt, has announced new waiting time targets for hospitals in Wales. The aim is that no patient will wait more than 12 months for an outpatient appointment by March 2006, down from the current target of 18 months, while the target for an inpatient appointment will remain at 12 months for March 2006. Monthly waiting figures have shown a reduction in waiting times. The announcement came as £264m for health services was allocated to reduce waiting times, improve key areas, and modernise staff pay structures in Wales. While the targets have been welcomed, there are concerns that Wales still lags behind England, and that capacity needs to be built into the system with sustained investment to ensure that Welsh patients do not receive a worse service than patients over the border.

Jonathan Sayeed, a Conservative MP, has announced his resignation due to health reasons after surviving an attempt to remove him from his position over allegations that he profited from private tours of Parliament. The MP denied the accusation of being paid to guide visitors around the Palace of Westminster, but was suspended from Parliament for two weeks and had the whip withdrawn for one month. Despite winning the vote to deselect him from his constituency association, Sayeed has now resigned from his role. The allegation was made by the Sunday Times, claiming that English Manner Limited charged clients for access to Westminster through Sayeed. The Standards and Privileges Committee launched an inquiry, and although Sayeed apologized for his conduct and denied the claims, he insisted that the committee's report had contained some factual errors. Sayeed had been an MP since 1997 for Mid-Bedfordshire, having previously represented Bristol East from 1983 to 1992.

According to a report by the government's finance watchdog, a number of errors contributed to the failure of the first attempt to sell the Millennium Dome after the close of the Millennium exhibition. The report cited a confusion of decision-makers involved in the sale, which cost £28.7m to maintain and sell over four years. However, a later sale to turn the Dome into a sport and entertainment venue was successful and could return over £550m to the public sector. While some officials praised the deal, others cautioned the government to ensure taxpayers get the full benefit of the sale. The previous attempt to sell the Dome was seen as a failure due to a confused and muddled process, but the successful sale was attributed to the hard work of government officials.

The amount of spam e-mails has increased by 40%, resulting in 90% of e-mails being junk according to Email Systems. This may cause concern for businesses trying to manage the overwhelming amount of spam in their email inboxes. While virus traffic has decreased, the firm has noticed a rise in denial of service attacks. The type of spam being sent has changed in recent months, with health-related e-mails being the most common, followed by gambling and porn. Fraudulent emails offering financial gain have declined by 40% in January, but there has been an increase in pornographic and medically motivated offers, possibly due to the low consumer motivation for financial products during this time of the year.

Quiksilver, a US surfwear company, is considering buying shares of Skis Rossignol, which resulted in a 15% increase in Rossignol shares. The owners of Rossignol, the Boix-Vives family, may accept the offer from Quiksilver, while other sporting goods companies like Nike and K2 are also possible buyers. The value of the US dollar decline has made a takeover of European sporting goods companies more attractive to foreign investors. The sale of Rossignol may result in an auction, increasing the sale price even higher. The Boix-Vives family has been exploring possible buyers for the past couple of years. Rossignol makes various sports equipment like golf equipment, snowboards, and sports clothing.

Sony will release its long-awaited handheld game device called PlayStation Portable (PSP) on 12 December in Japan, costing around 19,800 yen (145 euros). The device will come with 21 games, including popular titles such as Need for Speed and Metal Gear Acid. Although the release date for Europe and the US has not been announced, analysts predict it will likely be in early 2005. In the UK games charts, FIFA 2005 has regained its position at number one after briefly losing it to rival game Pro Evolution Soccer 4. Meanwhile, fans in Europe waiting for Gran Turismo 4 will have to wait until next year for the PAL version. Halo 2 has already broken video game records with pre-orders of more than 1.5 million in the US alone, and fans are eagerly anticipating its release on 9 November.

According to the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM), UK house prices slightly declined in November, dropping to an average price of £180,226 from October's £180,444. The UK housing market has recently shown signs of slowing down following interest rate hikes, and economists predict a drop in prices in 2005. However, annual house price inflation remains strong, having increased by 13.8% in the year to November. The ODPM figures are viewed as somewhat of a lagging indicator by economists, who believe the annual house price growth will weaken in the coming months. The ODPM attributed the monthly fall in prices to a decrease in the value of detached houses and flats.

Ten former directors at WorldCom have agreed to pay a total of $54m to settle a class action lawsuit, which includes $18m from their own pockets, for those who lost billions when the company collapsed due to an accounting scandal. The remaining $36m will be paid by the directors' insurers. The payout, if the directors use their own money, is said to set a new standard for the accountability of bosses in similar situations. The directors are expected to deny any wrongdoing by settling the case to remove uncertainties and costs of further litigation. Two other outside former directors remain defendants in the lawsuit, and former CEO Bernard Ebbers is facing criminal charges for overseeing the fraud.

Multi-purpose TV aids India Two-thirds of the world's population, 4 billion people, live on $2,000 a year or less. You might think that the last thing on their minds would be getting a television set or a computer. But that's not the case. Many people in the developing world give up one of their daily meals so they can afford to buy a TV. And now, an Indian-born computer engineer thinks he's come up with a way to give them cheap access to the internet. Carnegie Mellon Professor Raj Reddy has spent the bulk of his professional career trying to find ways to make technology accessible to poor people. The first step is to figure out why poor people would want a personal computer and Professor Reddy thinks he has a pretty good idea of why they might. "I come from a village," says Prof Reddy, "I know what the population is like, many of them are illiterate, and many of them have other concerns." "There, nobody will use it for the conventional uses of a PC, word processing and Powerpoint," he said. "So it's clear to me that if people wanted to use PCs in a village - it has to usable by illiterate people and it must be primarily for entertainment, education, telemedicine, and access to expert advice." Prof Reddy also thinks that tying it into some kind of aid package was the wrong approach. After all, he asked -- what aid group could possibly give expensive computers to 250 million less fortunate Indians, let alone the billions of poor people around the world? Instead, Prof Reddy decided to think of those 250 million Indians as a potential market. The problem then becomes one of making the product compelling enough. "It must be so compelling that you would give up your third meal in order to have this," Prof Reddy says. "People do this today with television sets. If you go to India, and many other countries, they will first go get a television set before they worry about one more meal. Why? Because personalized entertainment has become very important." This hatched a completely new idea. He calls it a PCtvt - A personal computer, television and telephone all in one that runs on a normal desktop machine. Literate users can surf through the applications with a keyboard and mouse but illiterate users can use what looks like a television remote control. On the screen, pictures - not words - designate applications like TV, voice mail, and video e-mail. This dependence on graphics, video and audio means that a computer for an illiterate person needs 100 times more power and more memory than one for a PhD. Prassana Rambathla, one of Prof Reddy's graduate students, says that "when you're talking illiterate you're talking audio and video, and that demands exponentially high bandwidth.' "It can't choke at any point in time, and it has to withstand anything no matter what you're pressing." "The major part is making it foolproof, very tough, so that it never breaks," he says. The Carnegie Mellon team says this project is only possible because PCs are now so much cheaper and have built-in audio and video hardware and software. Limited trials of the PCtvt are due to start this month in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. Although Andhra Pradesh has a fairly good infrastructure but work has to be done to ensure reliable connections to the net. Prof Reddy has teamed up with Eric Brewer at the University of California at Berkeley. The answer, says Prof Brewer, is wi-fi. "We're looking at the thing you'll see in Starbuck's or many other hotspots," he says. "We're doing a lot of work on long-distance wireless and how to make the network work better in the presence of intermittency, when the power goes up and down, and the links go up and down, and the computers you're connected to just get turned off for no reason." Prof Reddy says he hopes to lease the PCtvts for about $10 a month, and thinks Indians will rent the units for the television and DVD capabilities. Reddy says he can then introduce the PCtvt's other technologies - such as video mail. For example, a farmer could use the PCtvt's webcam to send a picture of a harmful insect to a local official who could send back a proposed course of action to the farmer. Prof Reddy thinks this kind of communication is the real pay-off. "The underlying problem," he says, "is how you can increase their wealth and reduce their poverty and reduce their illiteracy, and improve their health care.' "And what I'm postulating is that this is the technology that will enable them. If I didn't have it, it would be an uphill battle. Even with the technology it's an uphill battle. But I have a tool. There is hope. I can reach them in ways that have not been possible before." Clark Boyd is technology correspondent for The World, a BBC World Service and WGBH-Boston co-production

The real danger with online data is not what happens during transmission, but what happens when it reaches its destination. Criminals may be applying for jobs in financial institutions to gain access to customers' confidential data, which is valuable for identity theft. Even if people take precautions with their personal information, if trusted organizations are not capable of securing their databases, people are still at risk of identity theft. Companies like SecureWave offer solutions to restrict the use of USB ports to prevent data theft, but the issue of poor system security remains. The Data Protection Act is in place to prevent unauthorized disclosure of personal data, but penalties are small and the process of prosecuting under the Act is convoluted. Therefore, a more stringent data protection law or civil lawsuits against financial institutions may be necessary to pressure them to improve their security processes.

IBM frees 500 software patents Computer giant IBM says 500 of its software patents will be released into the open development community. The move means developers will be able to use the technologies without paying for a licence from the company. IBM described the step as a "new era" in how it dealt with intellectual property and promised further patents would be made freely available. The patents include software for a range of practices, including text recognition and database management. Traditional technology business policy is to amass patents and despite IBM's announcement the company continues to follow this route. IBM was granted 3,248 patents in 2004, more than any other firm in the US, the New York Times reports. For each of the past 12 years IBM has been granted more US patents than any other company. IBM has received 25,772 US patents in that period and reportedly has more than 40,000 current patents. In a statement, Dr John E. Kelly, IBM senior vice president, Technology and Intellectual Property, said: "True innovation leadership is about more than just the numbers of patents granted. It's about innovating to benefit customers, partners and society. "Our pledge today is the beginning of a new era in how IBM will manage intellectual property." In the past, IBM has supported the non-commercial operating system Linux although critics have said this was done only as an attempt to undermine Microsoft. The company said it wanted to encourage other firms to release patents into what it called a "patent commons". Adam Jollans, IBM's world-wide Linux strategy manager, said the move was a genuine attempt to encourage innovation. "We believe that releasing these patents will result in innovation moving more quickly. "This is about encouraging collaboration and following a model much like academia." Mr Jollans likened the plan for a patent commons to the way the internet was developed and said everyone could take advantage of the result of collaboration. "The internet's impact has been on everyone. The benefits are there for everyone to take advantage of." Stuart Cohen, chief executive of US firm Open Source Development Labs, said the move could mean a change in the way companies deal with patents. "I think other companies will follow suit," he said. But not everyone was as supportive. Florian Mueller, campaign manager of a group lobbying toprevent software patents becoming legal in the European Union,dismissed IBM's move as insubstantial. "It's just diversionary tactics," wrote Mr Mueller, who leadsnosoftwarepatents.com, in a message on the group's website. "Let's put this into perspective: We're talking aboutroughly one percent of IBM's worldwide patent portfolio. They filethat number of patents in about a month's time," he added. IBM will continue to hold the 500 patents but it has pledged to seek no royalties from the patents. The company said it would not place any restrictions on companies, groups or individuals who use them in open-source projects. Open source software is developed by programmers who offer the source code - the origins of the program - for free and allow others to adapt or improve the software. End users have the right to modify and redistribute the software, as well as the right to package and sell the software. Other areas covered by the patents released by IBM include storage management, simultaneous multiprocessing, image processing, networking and e-commerce.

China Aviation Oil, a scandal-ridden jet fuel supplier, has proposed to repay its creditors $220 million of the $550 million it lost through oil futures trading. The company hopes to make an initial payment of $100 million and then pay off the rest over the next eight years. In order for the offer to be successful and avoid bankruptcy, it requires the approval of creditors who include prominent banking institutions like Barclay's Capital and Sumitomo Mitsui, as well as South Korean firm SK Energy. Chen Jiulin, China Aviation Oil’s CEO, was arrested by Singapore police in December after the company’s trading debacle was announced in November due to a failed bet on the fall of oil prices. To make the immediate payment, China Aviation Oil will be using $30 million of its own resources while the remainder will be provided by its parent company, China Aviation Oil Holding Company in Beijing, which owns most of CAO’s Singapore-listed shares.

Joss Whedon, the creator of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, will write and direct the upcoming Wonder Woman movie. He views the character as the most iconic female hero of our time and is excited to explore the price of her power. The film will be produced by Joel Silver, known for producing the Matrix trilogy, and is said to be reinventing Wonder Woman for the 21st century audience. Whedon has a strong history in television production, having created seven seasons of Buffy and producing the spin-off Angel series. He is now directing the film Serenity, based on his sci-fi series Firefly.

Jack Straw, UK's Foreign Secretary, will join the UK delegation in Poland to attend the 60th-anniversary commemoration of the liberation of Auschwitz concentration camp, where between 1.1 and 1.5 million people, mostly Jews, were killed. The shadow foreign secretary, Michael Ancram accused the UK government of insensitivity and praised Jack Straw for finally representing Britain at this critical event. In the UK, the Queen and Prince Philip will attend a service in Westminster Hall, and the Queen will host a reception for holocaust survivors at St James's Palace. Meanwhile, Prince Harry has faced criticism after wearing a Nazi uniform at a costume party, and some Jewish human rights groups have called for him to attend the remembrance ceremony in Auschwitz.

Hyundai Motor, a South Korean company, has announced its plans to construct a second plant in India due to the growing demand for cars in the country. Although the details of the company's investment were not disclosed, the new plant is expected to produce 150,000 cars yearly, aiming to increase Hyundai's annual production capacity to 400,000 units, compared to being the country's second-largest car manufacturer. The company anticipates an increase in sales by 16% to 250,000 in India by 2005, with expectations to double the sales to 400,000 by 2010. The new plant will be erected beside the existing one in Chennai, located in the southern province of Tamil Nadu. Hyundai predicts a 15% growth in the Indian automotive market this year, which should reach 920,000 vehicles, expecting to attain 1.6 million vehicles by 2010. Demand for cars in India has been caused by the low level of car ownership and the poor state of public transport, with only eight people per thousand possessing an automobile. Plans are in motion to use India as a foundation for exporting products to Europe, Latin America, and the Middle East. The chairman, Chung Mong-koo, commented that expanding production is crucial for meeting the growing Indian auto market, which grows over 12% yearly, to surpass their competitors. The purpose is for Hyundai to become a global top five auto maker by 2010, controlling half of South Korea's market.

Sonny Parker's inability to recover from a trapped neck nerve means that Tom Shanklin will start in the center for Wales against England in Cardiff on Saturday. Hal Luscombe will take Shanklin's wing berth while Mefin Davies plays at hooker, Martyn Williams is fit to start at open-side, and Rob Sidoli replaces Gareth Llewellyn at lock. Williams will make his 50th cap, replacing the injured Colin Charvis who had a neck disc problem. Luscombe gets the nod on the wing ahead of Kevin Morgan, who wins a place on the bench alongside uncapped John Yapp.

Vivendi, a media company, along with its CEO and another executive, are being investigated by the French stock market regulator AMF for a complaint filed against them. The complaint states that the prospectus for one of Vivendi's bond issues was unclear and that the executives may have had access to privileged information. Deutsche Bank, the company that sold the convertible bonds to investors, is also being investigated. AMF believes that the executives knew about Marvin Davis' interest in Vivendi's US assets at the time of the bond sale and that they were considering exercising the right to buy British Telecom's shares in Cegetel. Vivendi denies these charges, stating that this information was public knowledge. This is not the first time Vivendi has faced penalties from AMF; they, along with their former CEO, were fined previously after misleading investors.

Premiership footballer and record company owner Kevin Campbell has applied for a court injunction to stop R&B singer Mark Morrison from releasing a new album. Morrison was signed to Campbell's record label and claims to have spent thousands producing his album, Innocent Man. However, Campbell is now attempting to prevent Morrison from releasing the album on Monday. Morrison plans to ignore the injunction and release the album, which is due for release on December 27. The case is set to be heard in the High Court on 20 December.

Labour's decision to choose a white candidate for a multi-racial constituency has prompted a race group to call for all-black shortlists. The contest for the West Ham seat in east London saw local councillor Lyn Brown selected from a group of two white and five ethnic minority women. The group, Operation Black Vote, stated that this result underlined the ineffectiveness of all-women shortlists in achieving representation for minority women. The group also called for talks with the Labour party chairman Ian McCartney about the wider issue. The Commission for Racial Equality (CRE) has also previously called for ethnic minority shortlists in certain situations. Ethnic minorities make up 8% of the UK population but only 2% of MPs. If they were represented in proportion to their numbers, there would be 42 ethnic minority MPs.

In a tennis tournament called the SAP Open in San Jose, American tennis players Andy Roddick and Andre Agassi, who were seeded as the top players, both had some trouble in their matches but managed to advance to the quarter-final stage. Agassi encountered difficulties early on against a left-handed player from Denmark named Kenneth Carlsen, but eventually won 7-5 6-1. Roddick also struggled, losing a set to a player from Korea named Hyung-Taik Lee, but he eventually pulled off a 6-3 3-6 6-2 victory. Other players like Jurgen Melzer and Cyril Saulnier also won their matches. Roddick expressed frustration with his own performance, but was determined to keep trying. Agassi, who has played in the tournament many times before, employed several techniques like lobs and quick net rushes to defeat his opponent.

Shares of the engineering group Jarvis have increased by 16% as they sold their 33% stake in Tube Lines, a London underground consortium, to Spain's Ferrovial for £146m ($281m). This sale brought in more money than anticipated and will help reduce Jarvis' debts of over £230m. Jarvis previously warned that it could go bankrupt if it did not secure a refinancing deal by January 2005, but now they have agreed with their banks to extend their credit facilities until March 2006. The company plans on scaling back its construction division and focuses on UK rail renewal, road repair, and plant hire work. The sale is beneficial for Ferrovial since they already have a 33% stake in Tube Lines and have been interested in acquiring more UK infrastructure assets. Alan Lovell, the CEO of Jarvis, said that the sale would significantly improve the company's financial situation and make it profitable in the future. As a result of this news, Jarvis' shares increased to 18 pence by the end of trading on Friday.

The Labour party has been accused by critics of using anti-Semitic imagery in a poster that depicts Tory leader Michael Howard as Fagin. The poster portrays Mr Howard hypnotising people with a pocket watch and claiming he can spend the same money twice. Concerns were raised by the editor of the Jewish Chronicle, but Labour insists it is anti-Tory rather than anti-Semitic. The party eventually removed the image from its website, replacing it with an alternative idea. A new poster featuring Mr Howard and Oliver Letwin with a blackboard showing 2+2=5 has been proposed. The previous poster has been compared to the portrayal of Fagin from the musical Oliver!, and another poster showing Mr Howard and Mr Letwin as flying pigs also drew controversy. Jewish Chronicle editor Ned Temko stated that the hypnotism image raised deeper concerns, bearing links with centuries-old prejudice. Labour spokesperson Fraser Kemp argued that the image merely portrayed Mr Howard as a hypnotist, with the message being that the Tories are trying to con people.

The Labour Party has decided to hold its autumn conference in Manchester instead of Blackpool, which is a departure from the usual seaside destinations. This decision was approved by the party's National Executive Committee, and it marks the first time since 1917 that Manchester will host the annual event. Blackpool will get the much smaller spring conference instead. The decision not to hold the larger conference in Blackpool is seen as a disappointment for the coastal resort, as political parties traditionally rotate between Blackpool, Bournemouth, and Brighton. The exact cost to Blackpool in terms of lost revenue for hotels is unknown, but it's expected that major Manchester hotels will receive block bookings after the official announcement.

Johnny Depp is a well-known actor famous for his unconventional and eccentric roles, and is often considered as one of Hollywood's most unique and maverick talents. Although he initially aimed to become a rock star, he found success as an actor after his wife introduced him to Nicolas Cage in Hollywood. He rose to fame with his role in the TV series 21 Jump Street as an undercover cop, and later became known for his collaborations with director Tim Burton. Some of his most memorable films include Edward Scissorhands, Donnie Brasco, and Pirates of the Caribbean, and he has also directed one film - The Brave. Recently, his role in Finding Neverland as JM Barrie received critical acclaim, showing his ability to capture the imagination of both adults and children. In his upcoming role, Depp is set to play Willy Wonka in a remake of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

Official figures have shown that strong consumer spending has helped accelerate US economic growth in the third quarter. The Commerce Department reported an annual growth rate of 3.7% between July and September, up from the 3.3% recorded in the previous quarter. However, this fell short of the forecasted rate of 4.2%. The increase was largely attributed to a significant rise in consumer spending, which accounts for two thirds of economic activity in the US. Despite the positive figures, analysts suggest that the economy may not be growing quickly enough to generate significant job creation. Nonetheless, President Bush is expected to use the report to support his policies, while economists predict that rising inflation means that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates in the near future.

Former England rugby union captain Martin Johnson has announced that he will retire from the sport at the end of the season. Johnson, who led England to a World Cup victory in 2003, will play his last match in June, which will be his testimonial at Twickenham. He has won 84 England caps and is the only person to captained the Lions twice. Johnson has also had a successful career as the captain of Leicester, guiding the team to back to back Heineken Cup victories along with several Premiership titles. Despite feeling that he could play for another season, Johnson believes it is the right time to retire and wants to leave the sport on the right note. His final match will see him lead a team against a side captained by famous New Zealand winger Jonah Lomu, who is returning after a kidney transplant.

Hereford and Doncaster played to a 1-1 draw and Hereford ultimately won 3-1 on penalties. Doncaster took the lead on the 59th minute with a stunning volley from Adriano Rigoglioso off Michael McIndoe's corner. Hereford equalized on the 72nd minute with a goal from Danny Williams just inside the penalty box. In extra time, McIndoe missed a penalty giving Mills the opportunity to score the winning goal on penalty kicks. The teams and subs are provided as well as the goal scorers and the attendance.

Tony Blair is being urged to use his influence to end the debt of poor countries and double the amount of aid they receive by Oxfam. The organization's report, "Paying the Price," states that approximately 45 million children will die unnecessarily by 2015, and aid budgets are only at half of their 1960 levels. Oxfam emphasizes that global poverty is an obligation and matter of justice, not just an act of charity. In 1970, G8 members agreed to allocate 0.7% of their incomes to aid; however, 34 years later, none of the members have reached this goal, and many have not set a timetable to do so. The report goes on to state the negative consequences of not investing in poor countries' sustainable development, saying that global poverty threatens global prosperity and security. Blair and Chancellor Gordon Brown have both called for urgent action to fight world poverty, and Blair has listed it as one of his G8 priorities alongside climate change and the AIDS epidemic. Brown pledged to forgive Britain's debts owed by poor nations, and the government is committed to reaching 0.7% of gross national income for overseas development aid by 2013. An International Finance Facility, if enacted, would allow the 0.7% goal to be achieved earlier, by 2008-09. The additional resources would be used to increase UK bilateral aid to Africa to at least £1.25bn a year by 2008 and spend at least £1.5bn on HIV/Aids related work over the next three years.

The BBC Radio 1 is set to launch the permanent replacement show for the late DJ John Peel. Three hosts, including Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank, will take on the show on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays, respectively. Despite the station's aim not to replace John Peel, but keep his legacy alive, critics doubt that the new DJs can fill in Peel's shoes. The DJs were chosen for their diverse musical expertise. The OneMusic show will play non-commercial and unpredictable tracks. Sara Cox will also return after taking maternity leave to host the lunchtime show on Saturdays. Some people suggested that the BBC should source new talent from internet radio stations like totallyradio.com, where Claire Kember is compared to the legendary John Peel by listeners.

In an auction held in London, a guitar that belonged to Jimi Hendrix was sold for £100,000. The guitar was a 1965 Fender Stratocaster and was part of a collection of guitars, records, and posters dedicated to the rock legend. The fan who collected the items, Bob Terry, sold it to another collector. Jimi Hendrix, who is widely considered one of the greatest guitarists of all time, died in 1970 at the age of 27 due to a drug overdose. Apart from the guitar, a poem written by Hendrix and his band's first single signed by all the members were also sold at the auction. The auction was hosted by Cooper Owen at the Hard Rock Cafe in London and was advertised as the biggest collection of Hendrix memorabilia to be sold at a public auction.

Security firm warns that Windows-operated ATM networks may be more vulnerable to computer viruses, as many banks are adopting this operating system for cash machines. There have been four reported incidents of Windows viruses disrupting the networks of cash machines, but some experts argue that these risks are being overstated. IBM's OS/2 operating system, which has long been used to power cash machines around the world, will soon no longer be supported, forcing banks to seek alternatives. Additionally, the move to Windows is being driven by other factors, such as the demand for upgraded cash machines to use Europay, MasterCard, and Visa's credit cards with computer chips, as well as US laws requiring equal access for disabled individuals. Anti-virus firm Trend Micro warns that the risks of using Windows cash machines are not negligible, with research showing that 70% of new cash machines run on Windows. Previous cyberattacks against Windows ATMs have caused cash machines to be unavailable for hours. However, since cash machines have a relatively long operating lifetime of up to a decade, the actual number of machines at risk may be limited, and banks may simply upgrade to new models as part of their usual replacement cycle. Some experts note that cash machines have built-in security systems to prevent spontaneous dispensing of cash, and that banks' main concerns are disruption of their internal networks and customer inconvenience. The Association of Payment and Clearing Services in the UK downplays the risk from viruses, stating that the country's tightly-knit community of cash machine operators and data network providers makes the threat minimal.

Cameroon's finance ministry has been hit with a salary scandal, resulting in a loss of 1bn CFA francs ($2m; £1m) per month due to widespread corruption. Around 500 officials have been accused of granting themselves additional payments or claiming salaries for employees that do not exist. Prime Minister Ephraim Inoni has promised harsh consequences for those responsible and has launched an anti-corruption drive. Investigations revealed irregularities in some civil servants' career structures, and some employees lied about their position to increase their salary. Criminal and financial action is being considered against those found guilty. The scandal has drawn attention to the country's generally opaque public finances and corruption issues.

The court has turned down Blackground Records' attempt to sue the video producer who booked the flight that led to the death of R&B singer Aaliyah in 2001. The court stated that only Aaliyah's parents had the right to sue for wrongful death. Aaliyah's family had previously settled a negligence claim in 2003. Investigations showed that the plane was overloaded and the pilot had cocaine and alcohol in his system. Aaliyah was a rising star who received many posthumous awards, including a number one single in the UK for More Than A Woman. The defendant's lawyer has yet to decide whether they will appeal the decision.

Jennifer Lopez cancelled her appearance at a charity premiere of her movie and album in the UK, claiming she was too sick to fly. She also cancelled all her European promotion for her new movie and album due to her doctors' advice. Her co-star Richard Gere attended the event, and the event had waltzing dancers on the red carpet, in reference to the film's ballroom dancing theme. The director of the film expressed disappointment with Lopez's absence due to her swollen glands. Other celebrities attended the event, including Honor Blackman, Tess Daly, and Anita Dobson. Lopez apologized for not being able to attend, and stated she was proud of the film and thanked those who were involved in its production. Despite her recent absence, Lopez performed at the Grammy Awards alongside her husband, Marc Anthony.

Blair is trying to appeal to Jewish voters and promises not to attack Howard's Jewish beliefs. He distances himself from recent Labour campaign posters that were criticized for being anti-Semitic and defends his party's attitude towards the Jewish community, pointing out that his government introduced the Holocaust Memorial Day. He refutes the idea that he would draw attention to Howard's religion to attract Muslim support and reiterates his support for the Jewish community and Israel. Meanwhile, London's Labour mayor Ken Livingstone is embroiled in a row over comments he made to a Jewish reporter from a newspaper, which Blair called on him to apologize for. Mr. Livingstone has not apologized, claiming he was targeted by the newspaper.

Liverpool manager Rafael Benitez expressed his happiness with the team's crucial win against Deportivo La Coruna in the Champions League group. Liverpool won 1-0, thanks to an early own goal by Jorge Andrade. Benitez was pleased with the team's defensive and counter-attacking skills, and thought they could have scored more goals. He praised midfielder Igor Biscan, who played well while replacing the injured Xabi Alonso. Benitez believed that winning was more important than where the match took place. Deportivo's coach, Javier Irureta, thought Liverpool played well and prevented his team from scoring. He acknowledged his team lacked imagination and confidence.

Mike Tindall's agent, Dipo Alli, has given an ultimatum to Bath rugby club to improve their current contract offer to the player before next week or risk losing him to another club. Alli has received an offer that far exceeds Bath's current deal and claims that two other clubs are interested in talking to Tindall. Alli states that Tindall does not want to go into the Six Nations tournament worrying about his future with the club. The decision rests with Bath owner, Andrew Brownsword, who has been reluctant to break the club's salary structure to accommodate Tindall's demands. However, Alli believes that Tindall's worth is more than what Bath has offered and wants the situation to be resolved by the end of next week.

Stan Lee, the comic book mastermind behind popular superheroes, has won a legal battle for a share of profits from the Spider-Man movies. Lee rose to prominence after creating the Fantastic Four in 1961, which changed the comics industry with its unique formula of characters having ordinary teenage issues in addition to superhuman abilities. Lee's Marvel universe gave rise to many well-known superheroes with a wide range of problems, such as drug abuse and social inequality. He gave credit to artists involved in comic designs, and his influence remains strong even today. Lee has started several ventures, including POW! Entertainment, which is currently developing movies and TV programmes. Despite previous business failures, Lee's creations remain popular, particularly Spider-Man, whose movies grossed almost $1.6bn worldwide.

Tottenham's manager, Martin Jol, praised his team's composure and professionalism during their 3-0 FA Cup win against Nottingham Forest. Jol acknowledged that Forest played defensively in the first half but were ultimately beaten by Tottenham's superiority. Looking ahead to the next round, Jol recognized Newcastle as a tough opponent but expressed confidence in his team's abilities. Tottenham's captain, Robbie Keane, echoed his manager's sentiments and emphasized the importance of securing the win, even if the performance wasn't pretty. Forest's manager, Gary Megson, admitted his team played poorly and deserved to lose.

The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) has announced that it has coped well with the growth of the internet in the last decade but says more work is needed in reaching the whole population. The IETF ensures the smooth running and organisation of the internet's architecture. With broadband take-up growing, services like voice and TV will open up interesting challenges for the internet. A new standard for information transfer and routing across the web, IPv6, will allow for billions more addresses on the net, meaning that the existing IPv4 will become obsolete. The net's growth and evolution depend on standards and protocols, and ensuring the architecture works and talks to other standards is a crucial job of the IETF. Security across the net is also a continuing concern, but the IETF is working to ensure there are better security internet standards.

The use of online games in politics gained momentum in 2004, with the US presidential election becoming a platform to reach out to a generation of players. The increasing prevalence of video games in culture and society was noted by experts. The Iowa Game, commissioned by Howard Dean, was the first official political campaign game, followed by more than 20 others. Artists and designers are using this form of gaming to make social commentary. Games are a powerful tool for interaction and modelling real situations in an original way. Players can learn about the world and themselves through gaming. Political campaigns will continue to experiment with video games as a tool of communication aimed at younger audiences that can integrate into the media ecology. Its impact will not replace other forms of political propaganda. It is estimated to take another decade before this breed of video gaming communication becomes a common political campaigning tool.

Bernie Ebbers, the former WorldCom CEO, has been accused of being personally involved in an $11 billion financial fraud committed by the company by Scott Sullivan, his former colleague and finance chief. Sullivan has been serving as the government's chief witness in the case against Ebbers. Ebbers, who denies multiple charges of fraud and conspiracy, has been accused of directing Sullivan to give false information on the company's finances to accountants. Ebbers' defense team argues that their client was not aware of the fraud and attributed the accounting practices to Sullivan. However, Sullivan claimed that Ebbers was well-informed on financial matters and heavily involved in cost-cutting measures. Sullivan has admitted to tampering with the company's financial statements, and his testimony could lead to an 85-year sentence for Ebbers if found guilty.

Life insurance provider Axa Sun Life has reduced its annual bonus payouts for up to 50,000 investors with-with profits policies from Axa Equity & Law. The bonuses have been cut from 2% to 1% for 2004 due to poor stock market performance. Axa has informed 3% of policyholders about the cut, while the rest will be notified in March. With-profits policies are designed to manage stock market volatility. In this case, the cuts mean that an investor who had contributed £50 monthly to their endowment policy for 25 years would see a reduced final maturity payout of £46,998, indicating an annual investment growth rate of 8%.

Charles Clarke, the new Home Secretary, has confirmed that the plans to introduce ID cards will continue, despite opposition from other political leaders. Charles Kennedy, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, called for a "pause for thought" following the recent resignation of former Home Secretary, David Blunkett. However, Mr. Clarke explained that he supports the use of ID cards as a means of creating a more secure society, and that the plans will be debated in Parliament next week. The Conservative Party has also expressed support for the scheme, with the police saying that it will be useful in their efforts to fight terrorism, immigration issues, and crime. However, some critics have warned that the introduction of ID cards may lead to marginalisation of specific groups of individuals, and could even drive some towards extremist behavior. The scheme will involve penalties for those who do not comply, including fines of up to £2,500, and the creation of new criminal offences related to false identification documents.

Michael Moore's documentary Fahrenheit 9/11, which is critical of George W. Bush, won best film at the US People's Choice Awards, voted for by the public. Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ won best drama. Julia Roberts won her 10th consecutive crown as favorite female movie star, Johnny Depp was favorite male movie star, and Renee Zellweger was favorite leading lady. Shrek 2 won three prizes. In television categories, Desperate Housewives was named top new drama and Joey was best new comedy. Will and Grace and CSI: Crime Scene Investigation were named best TV comedy and TV drama, respectively. Nominees for the People's Choice Awards were picked by an Entertainment Weekly magazine panel, and winners were chosen by 21 million online voters. Michael Moore dedicated his trophy to soldiers in Iraq, and Mel Gibson said he would not campaign for an Oscar, stating that "the people have spoken."

Elvis Presley's 70th birthday was celebrated around the world by his fans. In Blackpool, England, a three-day convention was held to find the best European Elvis impersonator. In the US, his home in Graceland, Tennessee, hosted four days of events, including a concert by the Memphis Symphony Orchestra. Jailhouse Rock became the UK's number one on Sunday. Fans in France held a tribute concert, and a special exhibition of Elvis memorabilia was displayed in Bonn, Germany. Record company SonyBMG released Elvis' 18 number one singles at the rate of one per week in Britain, complete with original artwork and a collector's box. The hit single One Night could become the 1,000th number one, as interest surrounding Elvis' birthday grows.
