Unlike Airbus, Boeing is focusing on smaller planes that can cover longer distances directly, without the need for connecting flights. The move is hoping to put Boeing back as the leading manufacturer in the airline industry. Boeing expects to sell around 500 of the long-range 777 planes over the next 20 years, with orders already taken from Pakistan International Airlines and Taiwanese EVA.

Martina Hingis has suggested that she may consider returning to professional tennis if her charity appearance at the Volvo Women's Open in Thailand goes well. The former top-ranked player expressed uncertainty about how her body will respond to playing again, but is using the opportunity to support her charitable causes and assess her current abilities. Hingis noted that the tournament has less demanding crowds and lower-ranked players than she faced during her previous career. The Swiss athlete retired at age 22 due to ankle surgery and played her last WTA event in 2002.

Russian debt has been upgraded from "speculative" to "investment grade" by Standard & Poor's due to the country's rising oil sales and budget surplus, making it a less risky investment. Despite recent issues such as the heavy tax bills and asset seizures imposed on companies like oil giant Yukos, S&P sees the solidity of government finances as outweighing any risk. Russia is now a net creditor and its gold and foreign currency reserves surpass its foreign public debt. While the other two major ratings agencies had already upgraded Russia's sovereign debt, S&P had held back due to concerns about economic and legal reforms. However, with the government's coffers full from tax revenues from energy sales, S&P now sees the government's own debt as a good investment. Nevertheless, S&P stresses that political risks, such as the Yukos saga, still exist and are a key ratings constraint on Russia.

According to Ed Balls, former chief economic advisor to Chancellor Gordon Brown, Brown will fulfill his golden economic rule with some extra margin. Balls hinted that there may be a Budget giveaway on March 16 and expressed hope for an improvement in tax credit rules. He also stated that a potential rate rise before the expected May election would not impact the Labour Party's chances of winning. Balls rejected rumors of Brown being sidelined in the election campaign and clarified that Brown was playing a different role. According to Balls, Brown's recent travels were to boost international development, and announcing the Budget date while on a trip to China was a sensible decision. Balls also commented on the possibility of an interest rate increase and said that it would not be a significant election issue or problem for the Labour Party. The exact date of the election is not yet known, but most experts predict it will be held on May 5.

Two reports suggest that mobile phones are not yet advanced enough to replace portable media players. While efforts have been made to bring music download services to mobiles, the size and battery life of mobile phones are challenges that need to be addressed. Gartner predicts that real-time TV broadcasts to mobiles are unlikely until 2007 in Europe due to technical issues and standards that need to be resolved. Additionally, limited storage on phones and the expectation of good quality images at low prices may also deter people from watching TV on their mobile phones. Mobile phone music services must not be placed to compete with the PC music experience, and mobile phones are not yet ready to replace portable media players. Nevertheless, more powerful smartphones are becoming increasingly common, and a report predicts that smartphone shipments will grow by 44% over the next five years.

Tottenham Hotspur's manager, Martin Jol, voiced his disappointment after a crucial goal by Pedro Mendes was not given during their match against Manchester United. Jol believed that his team was "robbed" of a win because the referee failed to utilize the available TV monitors to make the correct decision. Despite the referee wearing an earpiece, no action was taken. The ball had clearly crossed the goal line, but Tottenham was denied the goal, leading to a 0-0 draw. Jol acknowledged it was difficult for the linesman and referee to see the incident, but it was frustrating for him and his team. Mendes, the midfielder who took the shot, was surprised that the goal was not given after seeing a video replay. Both Manchester United's and Arsenal's coaches later argued that video technology should be used to support referees in uncertain situations.

David Miliband has rapidly ascended in the government and is now a minister in the Cabinet Office. He was elected in 2001 and previously held the position of school standards minister. Before the last election, he was part of the Downing Street policy unit and was a key member of the team that wrote the manifesto. Miliband is known for his intellect and has a family background in socialism with his father being an influential left-leaning academic. Despite being a Blair supporter, his brother Ed is a special advisor to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Miliband studied politics, philosophy, and economics at Oxford and later earned an MSc in political science from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Jason Gardener, a British athlete, won the 60m at the Leipzig International meeting despite being ill and suffering from an upset stomach. He clocked in at 6.56 seconds, equaling the meeting record, and beat out Germany's Marc Blume. Gardener almost went home due to feeling unwell but decided to run in the main race and everything went perfectly. Gardener, who was part of the Great Britain 4x100m quartet that won gold in the Athens Olympics, is now focused on the Norwich Union European Indoor trials. Other British athletes, such as hurdler Sarah Claxton and triple jumper Phillips Idowu, have also been performing well in indoor events.

The Berlin Film Festival has received a positive response to the German movie "Sophie Scholl - The Final Days," which tells the story of a member of the White Rose resistance movement who was arrested and beheaded by the Nazis in 1943 for distributing leaflets that opposed Adolf Hitler's regime. The movie is based on transcripts of Gestapo interrogations and Scholl's trial, and director Marc Rothemund worked closely with surviving relatives to ensure historical accuracy. The film is one of three German films competing for the Festival's top prize. Another film that premiered at the Festival is a South African version of Bizet's Carmen, performed by a 40-strong theatre and music troupe and the first South African feature film in 25 years to be nominated for a Golden Bear Award.

The dispute between the two heirs of Reliance Group, India's largest conglomerate, has affected the board meeting of one of its subsidiary companies, India Petrochemicals Limited (IPCL). Anil Ambani, the younger brother of Reliance Group president Mukesh Ambani and IPCL's vice-chairman, did not attend their board meeting following his resignation from the company earlier this month. Mukesh, who is also IPCL's boss, did not accept his resignation and the board asked Anil to reconsider his decision. Anil demanded the removal of Anand Jain, another board member, whom he accused of creating a rift in the Ambani family, but the demand was not met. The dispute between the brothers is affecting other companies within the group.

Michael Howard has denied that there was a split in his team over supporting the Labour Party's proposed plan to introduce ID cards. Although senior party figures reportedly had serious doubts about the strategy, Mr. Howard said that his cabinet had reached a "collective view" after a "good discussion." He also acknowledged that the matter was "not an easy issue," but decided to back the scheme because the police believed it would help fight terror, crime, and illegal immigration. The Liberal Democrats promised to oppose the bill, but the Conservatives said they would assess the cost-effectiveness of ID cards and ensure people's privacy was protected. Some party members and critics warned of the risk of driving people on the "margins of society" into extremism and undermining civil liberties.

Gordon Brown has presented his vision for New Labour's upcoming general election campaign. He believes that ensuring every child in Britain receives the best start in life could be a legacy equivalent to the creation of the NHS. Although he has previously planned the party's election strategy, this role will now be filled by Alan Milburn, a key ally of Tony Blair. However, the prime minister has promised that Brown will still have a significant role in Labour's campaign and praised his handling of the economy. In an article for The Guardian, Brown explained the direction he believes New Labour should take and emphasized the importance of delivering full employment and promoting education, good health, and sustainable communities. BBC political editor Andrew Marr suggests that Brown's article was a "warning shot" to Blair not to exclude him from the manifesto writing process. Blair, when asked about Brown's article and election role, stated that Brown's role would be "central" and childcare would be a "centrepiece" of Labour's manifesto. He also warned that the next general election would be a tough fight for New Labour and declared that the Tory strategy was to cut Labour's majority instead of aiming for an outright win via the back door. Despite speculation of a May 5th poll, Blair insists that he does not know the election date and is taking nothing for granted.

Andy Roddick has advanced to the final of the SAP Open in San Jose and will face Cyril Saulnier on Sunday. Roddick overcame Tommy Haas to defend his title, while Saulnier defeated Jurgen Melzer despite suffering an ankle injury during the match. Roddick was pleased with his performance and felt he was improving his returns. Haas expressed frustration at not being able to take advantage of his chances against a top-ranked player. Saulnier was thrilled to have made it to the final and credited his mental strength and hard work for his success.

According to the film's distributor, Hayao Miyazaki's latest movie, Howl's Moving Castle, is going to be released in 50 countries around the globe after setting a new record in Japan by making 1.5bn yen (£7.7m) in its initial two days. Miyazaki, who won an Academy Award for Spirited Away, became the first Japanese person to do so in nearly 50 years. Based on a fantasy novel by British author Diana Wynne Jones, the film tells the story of a girl who rapidly ages after falling under a witch's spell and goes on to search for a way to become normal again with the help of a wizard. The film is receiving a lot of interest from both domestic and international audiences and media, and will start its global release on 24 December in South Korea, and on 12 January in France.

The Arsenal manager, Arsene Wenger, expressed disappointment after their 3-1 loss to Bayern Munich in the Champions League and considered it their worst performance in the tournament. Despite Kolo Toure's late goal, Wenger acknowledged that they need to help Toure regain his confidence after his role in the two goals. However, he remained optimistic about the players' quality and spirit. Bayern's coach, Felix Magath, was also not pleased with the result, criticizing his players' failure to score a fourth goal and conceding a late one. Arsenal's goalkeeper, Jens Lehmann, took responsibility for the three easy goals they conceded but believed that with the goal they scored, they still have a chance in the second leg.

The Welsh rugby team's impressive performance in their Six Nations match against France has raised hopes of a potential Grand Slam win. The team's resilience and mental toughness in turning around the game and resisting pressure from the French team in the final minutes has been praised by fans and rugby legends alike. Despite past defeats, the team's recent progress, along with the emergence of young star players, has created a positive atmosphere within the squad. While the upcoming game against Scotland is the immediate focus, Welsh enthusiasts are already dreaming of emulating the legendary team of the 1970s.

Southampton's new manager Harry Redknapp will face his former club Portsmouth in the fourth round of the FA Cup. Other matches include Exeter City playing Middlesbrough if they can beat Manchester United in a replay, Oldham facing Bolton, Yeovil playing against Charlton, and Chelsea hosting Birmingham. Redknapp is positive about the draw despite previously walking out on Portsmouth, saying he is proud of what he achieved. Birmingham manager Steve Bruce considers facing Chelsea the toughest draw. The BBC will televise Exeter's replay against Manchester United.

The Bank of England is expected to keep the current interest rates of 4.75% unchanged in its latest meeting, despite having raised rates five times over the past year. This decision comes after signs of a slowdown in the economy, such as a fall in manufacturing output, decreased consumer confidence, and a cooling housing market. These factors have led to a belief that the economy has hit a "softer patch" after the initial rapid growth in the first half of 2004. The slowdown is considered temporary, with the possibility of rates increasing in the future.

The slow economy in Germany has resulted in the country having rising unemployment rates for ten consecutive months. While efforts to boost job creation have been made, a stagnant growth rate of 0.1% in Q3 has hindered positive change. High oil prices and the strong euro are also contributing to the negative effect on the job market. The eastern part of Germany is particularly affected, with an unemployment rate of 18.8%. The government is trying to tackle job creation with new initiatives, such as "one-euro jobs," but this has caused controversy and sparked strikes among some workers. Despite measures to prevent larger increases in unemployment rates, the situation in Germany's job market remains challenging.

Michael Douglas is co-producing and starring in an adventure film about a diamond robbery that takes place in India. The movie will be similar to Douglas's 1980s action films and will feature a Hollywood co-star and an Indian cast. The Indian studio prefers Aishwarya Rai for a lead role. The film is inspired by an article about India's money and diamond couriers. The production involves Douglas's company and two Indian film-making concerns. The film will have a significant Indian presence, including a train that plays a critical role in the plot. The film's predecessor, Romancing The Stone, earned Kathleen Turner a Golden Globe award in 1985.

A school in western Kenya is testing a pilot project that involves using handheld computers called E-slates to access digitized textbooks. The project is run by EduVision, a non-governmental organization seeking low-cost ways to provide updated information to students who still use ancient textbooks. The E-slates receive data transmitted from a satellite radio receiver and a base station at the school. The base station processes the information and turns it into content that can be read by the E-slates. The project is cheaper compared to setting up and maintaining an internet connection and regular computer network. While simple to set up, it's a one-way connection, making it difficult to get feedback or specific requests from users. The project is still in the pilot stage and is aimed at providing equal access to knowledge around the world. The team plans to extend it to remote areas by installing a solar panel to power the E-slates.

The Kyrgyz Republic is using a new technology involving invisible ink and ultraviolet readers to prevent multiple voting in its upcoming Parliamentary and Presidential elections, in an effort to show commitment towards more open elections. The ink is sprayed on a person's left thumb, and under normal light, it is invisible, but glows neon-yellow under ultraviolet light. The use of ink is controversial among pro-government groups, with some comparing it to the rural practice of marking sheep. However, other groups have lauded the move as an important step forward. The passage of the inking law is seen as a clear step towards free and fair elections, although the use of ink and readers is not a guaranteed solution to election-related problems.

A collection of postcards created by famous artists, including Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin, were sold out within hours after the annual Secrets sale opened at the Royal Academy of Arts. The identity of each artist was only revealed after purchase. There are still postcards available from other well-known artists, such as Mario Testino, priced at £35 each. The famous sale opened on Friday and ended on Saturday, with funds raised supporting the RCA's Fine Art Student Award Fund. Many of the contributing artists were either students or graduates of leading art colleges, and some famous individuals, such as Ken Loach, Hussein Chalayan, and Graham Coxon, also designed postcards for the sale.

The Prime Minister, Tony Blair, has apologized to two families who were wrongly convicted and sentenced to jail for IRA bomb attacks on pubs in Guildford and Woolwich in 1974. Blair expressed his deep regret that these families had been subjected to injustice and deserved to be publicly exonerated. The families hoped that the apology would be made publicly in the House of Commons, but Blair made it in his private room at Westminster. The wrongful convictions were based on scientific evidence that was later discredited, leading to the quashing of the sentences in 1989 and 1991. One of the so-called Guildford Four, Gerry Conlon, who was imprisoned for planting bombs, said the families were delighted with the apology and Blair had gone beyond what they expected. The apology followed a huge campaign in Ireland for a public apology, and the families hoped it would help heal their wounds.

Tony Blair has refused requests to publish advice on the legality of the Iraq War, leading to calls for an investigation. Conservative MP Michael Mates argued that the advice should be made public, claiming that previous legal advice had been published in certain circumstances. However, Blair claims that the matter has already been dealt with by Attorney General Lord Goldsmith. There have been allegations that Lord Goldsmith's statement to Parliament was drawn up at Number 10, but Lord Goldsmith denied being influenced by the government. The government has refused to publish the legal advice, arguing that these documents are confidential. Meanwhile, former minister Clare Short has called for a House of Lords committee to examine the issue.

France coach, Bernard Laporte, believes that his team will benefit from being afraid when they play against England on Sunday. Although they had a rocky start to the Six Nations with a weak performance against Scotland, Laporte hopes that the fear of playing England will motivate the team to do better. Laporte believes that the team is never as good when they are the favorite to win. In other news, Jean-Philippe Granclaude was thrilled to be included in the France squad for the first time and is excited to play against England. Laporte will announce the starting line-up on Wednesday at the French team's training center.
